text:
I had to give four stars as the recipe was written.

The taste is 5-star, but the instructions resulted in two little dry blobs of white flour in one of my mini loaves!!!  Unacceptable!

I would have been mortified had I served this to company!!

I think the steps need to be amended as follows:  CREAM butter and sugar, ADD eggs, one at a time, mixing after each addition, MIX in mashed banana, MIX in DRY ingredients to WET in three batches, scraping down after each, STIR in nuts.  It makes no sense and serves no purpose that I can see to *stir* in banana, eggs or dry ingredients.  They need *mixing* to be thoroughly incorporated.

I added 1 tsp vanilla and 2 tsp cinnamon. Used dark brown sugar/white in a 3:1 ratio.  Pecans instead of walnuts.

Have not tasted anything this great in a LOOOONG time!  The crust is fabulous, banana flavor is great, moisture is awesome!  And I read it will be better tomorrow!! 

Amazing.

text:
FINALLY! Someone who KNOWS what banana nut bread is supposed to be! Like others, I added 1/2 tsp baking powder, used half white and half dark brown sugar, and used pecans instead of walnuts. This is JUST LIKE MOMS! Thank you so much! I had tried two other recipes from this website and they turned out to be more like banana nut dessert cake, THIS is banana nut bread, it has substance! I used 3x8 loaf pans (it filled them just right), reduced the temp to 325, and cooked for about 70 minutes. They were a little too brown on the top, but that's just my bad electric oven, the humidity, and the combo of unbleached flour and dark brown sugar most likely. Mom would be proud of this bread! If you want something healthy to snack on, eat a luna bar, if you want something tasty, eat this bread! PS: If anyone wants to save a bowl and skip a step, I just mixed the wet mix as directed, then dumped the salt, baking soda, baking powder, and flour on top and mixed it all in at once. It turned out FINE.

text:
This is a great recipe for banana bread! What I love about it is its intense flavor. It's is unlike most banana breads in that it is very dense and quite moist. You can taste the butter in this bread along with the bananas--it practically melts in your mouth! My house smelled so YUMMY as the loaves baked. My family and I went through both loaves in just two days. Caution! It is highly addicting and hard to stay away from! The only changes I made to this recipe were #1. I added 2 tsp. vanilla #2. I used chopped pecans instead of walnuts & #3. I baked for 55 minutes instead of 60-70 minutes (this would have overcooked/burned the loaves)I have a 4 year old oven that bakes evenly/accurately. I would check the loaves of bread at 55 minutes before allowing them to cook any longer. This recipe easily earns 5 stars! My kids & hubby can't wait for the bananas to over-ripen! It would be hard to flub this recipe!

text:
I couldn't resist this recipe for some reason.  I passed on the one from this site with over 2000 reviews to see if this was as great as everyone said.  The reviews on the "other" one were really mixed not like this which were mostly 4 and 5 stars unless something went wrong.  I used 1 cup of white sugar and 1 of brown.  Used 1 tsp. each vanilla and allspice and had just barely 2 cups of bananas (4 whole bananas)I mixed the butter sugar mixture really smooth and added 1/2 the bananas to that as well so some were chunkier and some smooth and i also whipped the 4 eggs with the beater to get them fluffy.  Made one with walnuts and one without for picky family members. just by the smell and picking off part of the top i already knew it was going to be a hit! I was concerned with the amount of sugar but looks like i had nothing to worry about because it's fantastic!! Mine took exactly 1 hour and could have used about 55 minutes.

text:
Yikes. I have been making this recipe for three years now and I just discovered I had not yet reviewed it. This IS, by far, the best recipe ever for Banana Nut Bread. I have been baking for years and I don't dish out 5 stars for so-so recipes. For those of you who did not like it, you must have done something wrong- this is worthy of more than 5 stars in my opinion and any other person I know that has tried it feels the same. If you have a problem with darkening of the tops of the loaves, place a sheet of foil over the two loaves about 15 min before it is finished baking. It also makes great tea sandwiches by cutting small thin squares of EBNB, spread with mixed cream cheese and confect. sugar. Then place very thin slices of strawberry between two slices of EBNB that you have put the spread on. Beautiful and classy presentation, as well as delicious...

country:
None
text:
This banana nut bread is aaaaamazing. I followed some of the reviewers suggestions and added baking powder, cinnamon, and vanilla. 1 tsp of each just to make it easy.    As long as you combine all the wet ingredients together first and then slowly add the dry ingredients in 2-3 increments, you cannot go wrong.    wet: mix room temp butter plus sugar thoroughly first, then add beaten eggs and vanilla, followed by mashed bananas    dry:flour, salt, baking soda and powder, and cinnamon -give it a little stir    Finally add walnuts or pecans, then bake.    -I found that mixing brown + white sugar yields the same results as just using white sugar.     Thanks so much for the recipe and suggestions, my co-workers couldnt stop raving about it =D

text:
Holy Moly is all I can say...I only had enough banana's for one loaf so I cut the recipe in half.  I'm going to the store today to get more banana's so they'll be ripe this weekend - this was amazing!!!  I can't STAND when people rate recipes they've changed, but here I am doing it (but they're just slight changes!!!).  I added 1 tsp vanilla, a dash of cinnamon and used 1/2 white and 1/2 brown sugar.  I also changed the mixing "order" by adding the dry ingredients into the wet as it's easier to thoroughly combine that way.  The only bummer for me was the 350 degree oven cooked the bread too quickly so the outside was very dark.  Even with the bread being too done on the outside, this was hands down, by far, the best BNB ever.  I can't WAIT to make it again next weekend and lower the oven temp to get it JUST perfect. I'd give this 6 stars if I could!

text:
Found this recipe easy to make and even easier to add my own spin to it.  I would not recommend using banana extract as it overwhelms the taste of the bread and nuts.  A dash of vanilla extract was good.  And the recipe as written is enough to make a large bundt cake.  I used 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white.  Also lined my bundt pan with nuts and a little brown sugar before pouring in the batter.  I'll try to upload a picture.  You can add dried fruits like cranberries, raisins or little chunks of raw apples to this mixture with excellent results.  I really liked using this recipe and I want to thank Saseigel for posting it.

text:
This recipe prompted me to join allrecipes.com because I was so incredulous at its superlative rating.  First and foremost, let me state that, in my opinion, it is greatly over rated.  I mean no disrespect to Saseigel (or her mother) but this recipe - as originally submitted - turns into a greasy, overly-dense blob.  It does not rise.  It browns to an alarming degree.  It would be milk-toast bland had I not added a teaspoon of vanilla, 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg.  New cooks and seekers of  the perfect banana bread - beware.  Intermediate cooks, and above, this may be worth your consideration, but you will have to reformulate it, and, by then, it will be a totally new recipe so why start with a base that is so fraught with shortcomings?  I really wanted to embrace this recipe but, in all good conscience, can not endorse it on any level.

None
text:
This strange recipe makes wonderful banana bread that somehow taste light, in spite of all that butter, so you are tempted to overeat it.   I followed the recipe faithfully except I added the tsp of baking powder and I creamed the butter and sugar together as one cook recommended.  I am always cautious about over beating a quick bread batter especially once the eggs are added so I did NOT beat the eggs 'to make them especially fluffy' as another cook advised.  It is possible to toughen the crumb of a quick bread by incorporating too much air.   I blended carefully.  This bread was a huge hit at our house.

text:
Excellent, dense, full of flavor, very rich. JUST like moms! Note to others... if you want a "cake-like" light banana bread this is NOT the recipe for you. This makes a VERY heavy dense rich dark bread, think pound cake, except denser, or fruit cake, except tastier. If you like pound cake (or fruit cake, does anyone eat that stuff?), you'll probably like this banana bread. This is not an afternoon tea cake, this is a curl up by the fireplace with a mug of coffee (or milk) kind of cake.

text:
May 1, 2009 -  I gave this recipe 4 stars because of it's presentation.  I made this recipe last week for a breakfast function and got rave reviews for it and not one piece was left after the function. A few of my colleagues have already asked me to make it again.  I made these early in the morning and discovered that I did not have any walnuts, so I used pecans and raisins. However, I thought that it was too soft and it did not rise good enough.  Next time, I would use some baking powder with the baking soda.  Even though I sifted the dry ingredients, I still tasted the sharpness of the baking powder in some places.  I tried them in cupcakes but they were very flat.  Otherwise, the taste was great.   ******************************************                                      May 28, 2009 -  Voila!! I made a few adjustments and now I have the right texture. I decreased the butter to 3/4 cup and the eggs to 3.  I also used 1 teaspoon baking soda and two teaspoons baking powder.  I added a teaspoon of vanilla and a teaspoon of cinnamon and nutmeg each.  The batter was a little more stiffer and the loaves rose nicely.  I doubled the recipe and made three 9 x 5 loaf pans.  Again I got very good reviews.  One person who had a piece the last time commented that the texture was better.  This one is a keeper.

text:
thank you for posting such wonderful recipe! i was looking for banana nut bread recipe and yours was the first one i saw on google, with so many rave reviews it is proof its a great recipe. Although i did accomodate it for my own tastes, like chef sandra i used 3/4 cup of butter and slightly less sugar, only 1 and a 1/2 cup. I also added vanilla and pumpkin pie spice. I baked it at 325 because my oven tends to be very hot and let it bake for 50 mins. I covered the loaves with foil fifteen mins before the time was up because they were already a deep brown and i didnt want the top to burn before the inside was done. With the tweeks it tastes perfectly sweet not to sweet, and it has a yummy banana flavor and very moist! it is a lil dense so make sure not to over mix the dough because it can make it too chewy and dense. love it! it would make a good breakfast with some milk whenever your in a hurry! I love it with a glass of orange juice!

country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good banana bread for those  who prefer dense breads. It is similar to other recipes except it includes much less flour. I read the reviews about it not rising well, so I replaced the baking soda with baking powder because soda requires an acid in the ingredients to activate it. Mine did not rise much, but it did not sink in the middle either. After greasing my pans I did not flour them, but coated them with cinnamon sugar, and the point everyone commented on was the crust-it was yummy. I chose to use half white and half brown sugar and switched out the walnuts for pecans, adding some vanilla and cinnamon (which everyone liked). I lowered the oven temp after a little while and covered them with foil and they cooked through perfectly, not mushy or wet inside but still moist. The banana flavor was definitely present and I may make this one again with these modifications.

None
text:
Awesome Recipe!  Turned out great, like others I added a bit of Vanilla Extract and mixed equal parts of white and brown sugars.  You definitely need more than 1 cup of nuts, probably closer to two.  I mixed walnut and pecans which was a good idea if you ask me.  Also, I added Semi Sweet Chocolate chips (about 3/4 of a standard bag), then sprinkled some additional nuts and chocolate chips on the top after I poured the batter into the pan.  They turned out tasting like the Banana Chocolate Chip muffins from Paradise Bakery, only with nuts.  Just a wonderful recipe overall though!  Highly recommend it.  Remember, because of the way this recipe is constructed, the bread will turn out only about 2 1/2 inches high, which increases the density and the moisture, so don't expect it to rise to the top of the pan. Convection ovens are great and will make this bread finish at the 50 minute mark at 350 degrees.  Cook a little longer for a stronger "crust" like top.  Thank SASEIGEL whoever you are!

text:
This bread was 'Extremely' greasy! I was looking for a rich and moist banana bread recipe, and I guess my personal definition of 'rich & moist' is way off because this is not what I had in mind. Sure, it is rich and moist, but not in a good way... It's just so greasy that it ruins the experience of enjoying this bread. It does, however, taste delicious, but the taste alone is not enough to make up for the very obvious flaws and first impression. Also, followed the recipe EXACTLY, and the loaves didn't rise and sank in the middle when I took them out. I was planning on sending these to work with my husband, but not anymore... I would rather not be embarrassed by their terrible appearence and extreme greasiness! I think this recipe, because it tastes so good, could be salvaged with a bit of tweaking... perhaps either more flour, or less butter, and the addition of baking powder to help with the rising, as baking soda just wasn't powerful enough. Overall, I'm very disappointed with the turn out, but am atleast consoled by the fact that the loaves are edible and I don't have to waste them... they just can't be seen by ANYONE other than my husband and I. (yes, they are that bad!)

text:
I have baked this banana nut bread but after years of cooking and almost as many years using another banana nut recipe, I couldn't bake it without making a change in the ingredients.  I believe I found an error in them.  I think the baking 'soda' should be 'baking powder'.  That's why some people are getting flat bread because it's the baking powder that makes it rise. At least that works for me and I thought I'd pass it along so you can use it if you wish.

Not the best banana bread I've ever made.  Very little rise to it, so it was particularly dense, and I adjusted the baking soda/powder ratio. I decided to make this banana nut bread because it had such great reviews. The only thing good I can say about it is it was very easy to make. That's why it got 3 stars from me. But in saying that I think that's where the problem is. Sometimes you have to put a little more effort into something to make it special. This was not special. First of all I noticed right away that there was no vanilla listed in the ingredients. I don't like to rate anything unless I've followed the recipe to a "T". So I left it out. Big mistake. This bread really didn't have much taste at all. Especially not banana! Disappointed. Also, an entire cup of butter is TOO much! I could have probably used half of that. The bread was very greasy as well. Along with no taste and the grease, I threw the entire thing in the trash. Sorry. I don't understand what all the fuss is about this recipe. I'll stick to my more complicated recipe that has lots of flavor and much less grease.

text:
OMG! The best recipe ever.  Because my husband is diabetic I lowered the sugar by replacing 1 cup of sugar with 1/2 cup each of brown sugar splenda & regular splenda.  From prior readers recommendations I added 1 tsp vanilla, 1 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp baking powder.  I only had two ripe bananas so I filled the 2 cups needs with pulp I had from my juice I made (apple, oranges, strawberries,tomato & carrots).  It turned out wonderfully moist and tasty.   Now I have a recipe to fall back on when my bananas go ripe instead of throwing them away.  By the way, I made this bread in a bundt pan and baked it for 55 minutes.

text:
With so many reviews I just had to try....I took some of the ideas that everyone listed & tweet it for my needs.  To cut down on calories, I substituted 1/2 cup of applesauce for 1/2 cup of butter.  I also divided the 2 cups of white cane sugar & used Splenda, Dark Brown Sugar & White Cane Sugar.  I also added 1 teaspoon cinammon, 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract, 3 dashes of nutmeg, 1 teaspoon baking powder, 4 oz mini chocolate chip morsels(all I had) & 1 - 1 1/2 cups of pecans.  PERFECT mixture for bundt pan & mini muffins & OH SO YUMMY!!!  TY all for sharing & happy baking!!!

text:
GREAT RECIPE! Not the typical heavy banana bread. Perfect consistency, no matter what substitutions you use.  Works good with 1/2 white & 1/2 brown sugar, oil and butter combos, and/or adding vanilla.  I have made it as written and with modifications and always great.  I always omit the nuts due to nut allergies in our family, but never a bad batch.  I add a sprinkling of cinnamon sugar atop for a flavor touch to the crustiness. DON'T LISTEN TO THE COMPLAINERS THAT THERE IS TOO MUCH SUGAR!  If you don't want sweet bread...don't make one!  Pretty hard not to be sweet when it is a sweet bread with 2 cups of sugar. Duh!

text:
Excellent recipe. I didn't change the ingredients, however, I did change the order in which the ingredients were mixed. I creamed the butter and sugar together, then added each egg and beat the mixture thoroughly between each egg. I then added the bananas and then the flour mixture. The walnuts were last. I am going to try to add some vanilla to kick it up a notch next time. This is a wonderful recipe - it came out moist and tasty. I definitely recommend!

text:
My husband absolutely loved it!
Here's what I did:
Cream butter(not melted) and sugar with whisk until light and fluffy. Then, add and beat one egg at a time. Add and beat 4 ripened bananas. Add and beat sifted dried stuff into the 1/4 wet mixture. Repeat this 4 times. Add 1tsp Vanila and beat. Pour the mixture into the mold and baked at 325 degree(mine is conventional, so had to lower the temp by 25 degree) for 60 mins. It came out great! Thanks for the great recipe!!!

text:
This banana bread is AMAZING.  Like other posters, I used 1 cup Dark Brown Sugar and 1 cup white sugar.  I also used 1 tsp (or more) vanilla, 1 tsp cinnamon, and 1/2 tsp ground nutmeg.  Also, 1/2 cup extra chopped walnuts and 1/2 tsp baking powder.  I usually go a little over on the bananas too and the fat content is a little more than necessary (I use 10 tbsp butter and 3 tbsp vegetable oil).  The base for this recipe is incredible though.  Even if you make it exactly as the recipe says, it's still great.  I literally melt when I eat this bread.  Excellent, excellent, excellent.

text:
OMG My house smells amazing!!! ok so i may have jumped the gun rating but i couldnt resist.
i did have to make a few adjustments because i live at high alt. i only put 1 1/2 tsp baking soda, and added about 1/8 cup extra flour , cut the sugar (1/2 brown 1/2 white) by a half cup and raised the oven temp to 360. if it doesnt come out right, it is due to my error trying to adjust for the altitude. but AMAZING recipe :)



UPDATE- It came out PERFECT! will be making this again
Anyone living at high altitude shuld make the adjustments i did and you will not have a problem
-bake at 365-65
-cut sugar by 1/2 cup
-cut soda  by 1/2 tsp
-add 1/8 cup MORE flour

text:
Wow made as is this is dense and wonderful. It also has enough liquid to hold up well to adapting using gluten free flour. It is so good. I debated over the addition of cinnamon, etc. I am tired of everything tasting the same because of the cinnamon, etc. addition so I left it out of this. And I'm glad I did. I did add a hefty tsp or so of vanilla. This is a great bread. I didn't add baking powder and perhaps it would have helped it to rise, but I believe it is intended to be dense and it is so yummy made as is, with the addition of vanilla, and using the walnuts as indicated. Glad I made as is. YUMMY! 5 STARS! Thanks for sharing!! OH and for those who are wondering the butter should be softened and could even be melted (i suppose). I used it softened. Perfect!

This is the best recipe!!  I have never made banana bread, and I tried this recipe, because I am going to be making a variety of bread to give out as christmas gifts this year.  This is definately a keeper!!  The only thing I did differently is added a tsp. of Baking Powder.  Turned out great!  This bread was super moist, and I gave a loaf to my mom.  4 days later, she had a piece left which I ate and it was still just as moist as the day I made it.  Definately worth making.  Health warning is right though...it is hazardous at home and don't eat the batter!! LoL. It is hard to control yourself.

text:
Fabulous recipe! My whole family loved it, even my daughter who dislikes nuts. I substituted whole wheat flour since we try to stay away from the white. It turned out great. I also substituted pecans for the walnuts. I mixed together all the ingredients except the whole wheat flour and then slowly added the flour without over mixing since I wanted the bread to rise. I have had baked goods rise poorly when I stir too much. Thanks so much for sharing this wonderful recipe. I am taking it to my Bible Study tomorrow and I know they will love it!

text:
I have made this recipe twice now, and it's turned out well both times.  The first time I made it, I made the following changes:  1 cup white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar, 1tsp vanilla.  The bread had good flavor, but was really greasy.  The second time I made the bread, I only used one stick of butter and added two cups of natural applesauce.  It turned out great!  I recommend this recipe to everyone, especially new bakers as this was really easy to follow.  My only recommendation is to cut back on the butter.

text:
This is the best banana bread I have ever tasted and my husband just loved it.  You are so very right the one loaf was gone in one day, and it is just the two of us.  I like experimenting so this is what I did and it was fantastic.  I used 1 cup of white sugar and 1 cup of light brown sugar.  I only had 1 1/2 cup of bananas so I used 1/2 cup of drained crushed pineapple, and also added 1 teaspoon of cinnamon and some flavoring 2 teaspoons of homeade vanilla extract and 1 teaspoon of banana extract.  It was great and wrapped in the aluminum foil to keep in the moisture was a great tip.  I just put a batch in the oven, but used smaller pans, like that I could share or put some in the freezer to enjoy another time.  My husband likes his with a little ice cream.

None
text:
This recipe EASILY gets 5 stars from me. It's perfect in every way. So buttery, nutty, and rich! I have to give half of it away so I don't wind up eating it all myself. I tweaked the recipe to my liking a tad: split the sugar in half equally with white and light brown sugar. Added a tsp of good vanilla extract, and a tsp of ground cinnamon. Also, added about another cup of chopped walnuts. Didn't want the rest of the bag going to waste, and who doesn't like more walnuts? I probably ended up adding an extra  quarter cup of mashed bananas. Had a two left I didn't want to waste. Gave the loaves a turn half way through cooking for a more even bake. All in all, I won't be using any other recipe for banana nut bread. The boyfriend is in LOVE with it, and he doesn't like banana bread! Highly recommend.

text:
This was so good I am making it again tomorrow. To be on the safe side I ran the baking soda and baking powder through a sifter. The recipe does not call for the baking powder, but I added it based on other reviews. FYI, 4 medium bananas is two cups of mashed bananas. 

I did not make the loaf, but rather a batch of jumbo sized muffins, and a batch of regular cupcake sized muffins.  Make sure and spray Pam to keep muffins from sticking.

You'll have to bake for a shorter time, but I just sort of eyeballed the muffins and tested them when I felt they might be done.

This is probably the best recipe I have ever found anywhere. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I made this the first time ever and it is just perfect! Mmhhh, this lovely smell in the kitchen:) I didn't change much, just added a hint of cinnamon. I mixed the walnuts in last, coating them in a little flour before so they don't sink to the bottom. I used half the dough to make a bread and the rest made 12 muffins, just so I could eat some while they bread was still baking:) It was rather light and fluffy, maybe because I only had cake flour left, but still very good. The only thing I might change is using other nuts, the walnuts are rather dominant in taste! But still, a great and easy to follow recipe!!!

This bread was so greasy!  The flavor was good, but it got VERY dark, wouldn't come out of the pan, and I even had the oven at 325 degrees and covered it the last 20 minutes with foil. I was very surprised this received so many positive reviews - we have made many pans of banana bread in our baking experience, but this one is not a keeper for us.

text:
I've been a good cook for 50 yrs and never made a banana bread, but have eaten it many times and loved it. I decided to try this one since it had so many rave reviews and I had 4 bananas ready to do something with. I am hugely disappointed. I didn't change anything except for adding vanilla. It rose beautifully, but was way too brown after 30-mins. I lowered the oven to 325 and cooked til a total of 50 mins. It was too done. too brown, and not nearly flavorful enough. I can't imagine why all the praise for this one. Maybe a lot of today's cooks don't know what it's suppose to taste and look like. I just know I'll be more skeptical of reviews in the future and will be hitting my friends up for their recipes for banana bread soon. Happy baking!

My first time making this recipe. I added 1 tsp. of nutmeg, cinnamon, and vanilla extract and instead of 2 cups of white sugar I did 1 cup of white and 1cup of brown sugar. Love Love this bread....the only thing I did a little different was I used 1/2 cup of butter and 1/4 cup of lowfat vanilla yogurt (yes yogurt can be used as a substitute) for the 1 cup of butter. text:
We liked it very much warm, somewhat less if it's room temperature, and not at all cold. This is probably because I replaced half the butter with applesauce. Then again, we like cold applesauce..so who knows. I added cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla because really..no spices? None? I baked this recipe in a bundt cake pan for 50 minutes and it was perfectly done and moist. (Dusted the top with powdered sugar--may do a glaze next time.) I have to wonder if all these people raving about this recipe made it as written or if they read the reviews and changed things, because as written, it's pretty bland...

text:
Sorry, didn't think this was as great as everybody raved about.  First of all, it stuck in the greased and floured pans.  Secondly, I can taste the butter, but not much other flavor.  That could be my bananas, as there were very ripe, but not what I would call OVERripe.  I even followed previous reviewers' suggestions and added cinnamon and vanilla.  I did substitute part of the baking soda for baking powder to help with it rising a bit.  I used the correct size pans (even measured them).  The bread did not crown in the middle, as usually happens.  It is thoroughly cooked, much darker than most banana bread, but I attribute that to the excessive amount of butter and sugar.  It is not burned.  After about 45 minutes, I covered it with foil to keep it from browning too much, but it is a nice, rich dark color all the way through.  Like I said--way too much butter, the bread itself is greasy, and nothing to rave about.  I'm deleting it from the "saved" recipes.  Sorry for the ingredients involved (1 LB of butter, 4 EGGS and 2 Cups of sugar) I would expect more.

text:
This was an outstanding recipe. My search is over for the perfect Banana Bread Recipe. So quick and easy to make. And definently habit forming.My 2 loaves were ready in 63 minutes exactly.The only changes I made were: adding a teaspoon of cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg,a teaspoon or 2 of vanilla extract and one cup of each, brown and white sugar.I never added the nuts to the batter. I chopped up some pecans and mixed them with a couple tablespoons of brown sugar. I then took that mixture and sprinkled it on top of the loaves before baking. The first time I made this recipe I used some vanilla and banana extract. Today I found some french vanilla extract at the store and tried it. Can you say yummy!!! My stomache is still smiling. In the past 2 weeks I have made this recipes 3 times. And I plan on making it again tomorrow night.Thanks for sharing!!!!

text:
Made this on a whim since you can use melted butter, thus no pre-planning.  I couldn't find my loaf pans which are packed away somewhere. Instead I made muffins.  They were terrific.  I filled the muffin cups almost to the top and it made 2 dozen.  Since this recipe doesn't rise too much they turned out perfect.  I baked them for 17 minutes at 375 degrees, but next time I'd lower the temp to 350 and play it by ear on the time--the bottoms were slightly overdone.

Delicious recipe.....I made it as written just substituting pecans for walnuts.  I really like that the banana flavor shines through without the brown sugar and spices to compete. Thanks for sharing such a good recipe!!

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe is exactly what it says, extremely delicious, easy, and adaptable to your tastes.  We didn't have any butter and I was forced to use vegetable oil and the recipe still came out delicious and moist.  Also, since I'm in Colombia, Brazil nuts are cheaper and more readily available here so I substituted those out too.  It was a complete success.  I grew up eating banana bread because I'm from the USA, but no one here had ever had it before and EVERYONE was begging me for the recipe.  I have a gas oven and I, too found that the cooking time was more like 55 mins.  Also, here most households have azucar morena, which is basically raw granulated sugar (the brown kind) and I always substitute the raw sugar for any type of sugar, white or brown, and all of my recipes come out perfectly. I do a lot of baking and sometimes it's hard to find specific ingredients being outside of USA. That's why I was so glad this recipe was very basic.  Everyone has these ingredients in the cupboard. Next time, I think I'll try to use butter and make the extra additions of vanilla extract and cinnamon that other people have mentioned.  This is a great basic recipe  and it tastes just like my Mom's. Thank you!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the absolute best banana nut bread ever! I've made it about 10 times now and will never use another recipe. (I'm getting ready to make it again today.)

UPDATED 12.12.09: While I still agree that this recipe is THE best one ever, I decided to make a few modifications based upon some of the comments. From the start, I split the sugar so it's 1 cup each white & brown sugar. I also added 1 t. vanilla extract & 2 t. cinnamon. Today I decided to also add 1/2 c. of rolled oats and 1/2 cup of dried, unsweetened cherries. I also upped the overripe bananas to 2.5 cups. Baked it for 65 minutes (altho I checked it at 50 minutes w/a toothpick, then again at 60 min - be sure to reset your oven to 350 degrees after checking because it loses heat during the process!). I let them cool, wrapped each in plastic wrap, then alum. foil. Put one in a zip freezer bag & put it in the freezer for Christmas. The other one went in the fridge for a couple hours. We just pulled it out to try it & decided to KEEP these new additions. Thanks SASEIGEL for posting the original version!!

This BNB is truly amazing but talk about sugar-bomb!! As others have said, you really can only have so much of it. I baked the mini loaves at 325 deg for 35 min.  So moist and sweet, it was definitely a winner at my household!

An excellent and tasty bread. I used half white and half brown sugar and put a tsp of almond extract in. Delicious. Resist eating too much, it's very heavy in your tummy. Also, be sure to let it cool for the 2 hours in the fridge. Eating it too early makes it seems almost greasy. Follow the instructions and this bread can't be beat!

text:
I'm not sure how the recipe "as is" might turn out.  I was not inclined to make the bread until I read some of the reviews.  With the changes, it was totally deee-licious.  I creamed the sugars and butter; added 1 tsp. of baking powder; split sugars between granulated and brown; added eggs one at a time, blending after each one; used a very full 2 c. of banana (I freeze bananas that have gone ripe----in their skins); Added dry ingredients about 2 cups at a time on blend speed of my blender; I used my blender throughout. Stirred in one cup chopped walnuts.  It turned out so great that I can't stop eating it.  Was a huge success at a meeting I just hosted.  Thanks for a great start with the original ingredients.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
EBNB - WOW! This was delicious - heavenly! It was flavorful, very tender (don't over-mix, which causes gluten to form), as well as dense and moist (it is not supposed to rise a lot - like brownies). Creaming the butter and sugar is important for a dense, moist crumb and for a slight rise: when you cream them, they can hold gas that arises from the baking soda. Melted butter will make an even denser bread and cold butter will make it more cake like. I added vanilla (2 tsp) as recommended by other reviewers. I prefer raw granulated sugar to more moist brown sugar for this recipe, which gives it a delightful crisp on the crust. If your bananas are very, very ripe (sweeter and therefore, less acidic), you might get a better rise with baking powder, but you will have to use more (1.5 tsp per cup of flour, or 3 tsp for 2 cups). This was a keeper, and it's hard not to eat the entire loaf in one day. Thank you for the recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe.  I made it today and it came out perfectly.  I cooked it at 345 degrees for approximately 60 minutes.  I sifted the flour 3-5 times because I used all purpose flour.   I also used organic walnuts which I had to crush myself. I used the kitchen-aid stand mixer to whisk everything together. 

I would agree with Virginia Sista that you must cream the butter.  Sift the sugar and then add it to the butter.  Continue to beat it until it's nice and smooth.  Although the ingredients didn't say to do this - I generally cream butter when making pound cake from scratch so I just figured that it would work well in this case.

Also I notice that when using the stand mixer that I still have to stop the beating and manually stir the mixture to make sure that there isn't flour sitting at the bottom of the bowl.

text:
Haven't read all the reviews, so I may be repeating some. Just took the loaves out of the oven an hour ago, so all I've had is one nibble--great, as expected. Substitutions I made: Had no baking soda, so used 2 Tbs. of baking powder. Didn't have enough butter, so used half butter, half olive oil. Instead of 2 c. white sugar, I used 1 c. plus 1/2 c. molasses. Didn't have 2 big enough loaf pans, so I used the one I had plus a smaller one and a small Pyrex casserole dish. Everything tested as done after 45 minutes, so out they came. Lots of alterations, so my rating applies only to the resulting hybrid. Bottom line, at least for me, is that you can adjust this recipe--and doubtless many others--ad lib to suit what you have on hand and your preferences. And still end up with a winner!

text:
This was wonderful! I've never made banana nut bread before and it turned out great. I did change a few things:
Instead of 2 c white sugar I did 1 c brown sugar and 1 c of white sugar. I subbed 1/3 c butter, 1/3 c coconut oil and 1/3 cup apple sauce to make it slightly healthy (less butter) added 1 tsp of vanilla. I added 1 1/2 tsp of baking powder and didnt use any baking soda. I also baked them in muffin pans at 350 for 32 min. Be sure to cream sugar with butter and beat eggs before mixing them in the sugar butter mixture. Will make again :)

text:
I loved this bread. I followed the suggestions from a few users and added an extra 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda, 1 tsp of vanilla, 1 tsp of cinnamon and used 1 cup each of brown and white sugar. These were great ideas!
I also swapped 1/2 cup of the butter for virgin coconut oil, swapped out 1/2 cup of the white flour for 1/2 cup a mix of whole wheat flour with 1 tsp each ground chia and flax seed. This added health benefit but did not compromise the moisture or flavour at all!

text:
Hi everyone! I'm mexican and love cooking. I have many american friends as well as canadian and I know they can bake whereas most mexican women cannot do it as nicely.

So I met my first banana bread some 3 years ago and my friend, Yolanda Brunner, helped me to learn to how make it. Sadly, though, I lost the recipe, and then I googled it, encountered this recipe, read the reviews and venture to bake.

I've made the EBNB twice and absolutely loved it!

In the altituted of my hometown, it takes only 50-55 minutes (Aguascalientes, city). I cut the sugar to 1.5cups to 1.75cups and added almonds since it's what I had available. I added 2/3 (or so) teaspoon of baking powder, reduced the amount of the salt and soda to a little less.

Well, thanks for sharing this and eventhough I agree instructions are drafted a little messy, most people can understand what they should do as long as the love baking.

Tania, from Aguascalientes, Mxico.

Thanks again

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been searching for a good banana bread recipe that would work at high altitude for almost 15 years. This is the only one I have finally had success with!  Of course I did have to make a few small tweaks for my 8'900+ elevation, which are the basics of baking at high altitude: adding more flour and liquid and decreasing the sugar and leavening.  I also added a pinch of baking powder, two tsp. pure vanilla extract and used pecans. I could tell as the loaves were baking that this was finally it! The loaves didn't bubble over or stick to the pans like all the other recipes I've tried. They are a dark loaf, and mine came out with  concave tops, so maybe not the most attractive loaves - at least in my case - but who cares when they taste this good?

text:
This is without a doubt the best banana bread I have ever tasted.  I did as one reviewer suggested and creamed the sugar and butter together and then added the eggs one at a time.  I did add 1 tsp of vanilla, although I am not sure it would have needed it with all that yummy banana flavor.  I added the 2 cups of mashed ripe bananas (about 4-1/2 bananas), and then added the dry ingredients that I had previously stirred up.  I mixed that up and then added the nuts.  I could not find my loaf pan, so I simply greased and floured a 9 x 13 cake pan and baked it for 50 minutes.  We ate it in squares instead of slices and it was simply perfect.  This is the only banana bread recipe I will ever use.  Thank you so much for sharing such a wonderful recipe with us.

city:

country:

text:
LOVE this recipe. I usually always make carrot bread for x-mas but wanted to make something different this year & stumbled up on this recipe. My first banana nut bread and I have to say that this beats my carrot bread by far.
I made a few changes though- I put 1/2 Cup vegetable oil 1/2 cup butter. All dark brown sugar & to make it extra moist I blended 1/4 cup of pineapple, 1/4 cup of peaches to the 2 cups of banana & added 1tsp. vanilla extract & blended together to make the bread extra moist & smooth. Then grinded up the walnuts and toasted them at 350 for about 15 minutes & added it to the dry mix. 
Everyone raved over this EBNB. My boyfriend even liked it better than my carrot bread & that says a lot. Thanks!

text:
I had been using a different recipe for years until I tried this one. This makes such a dense, moist, flavorful banana bread. My husband and neighbors love it. This is my new favorite recipe. The more overripe the bananas, the better the taste. I follow the recipe except I don't add the nuts. I think I will try adding baking soda next time as others have suggested. My second batch really fell when they came out of the oven for some reason. But this is a keeper, will certainly make it again.

text:
Best BB ever!  I usually use this recipe and tried a different one recently and was very disappointed.  You can stop looking for a BB recipe here!  You can alter this with good results every time.  I used 6-7 bananas since I had that many that were super ripe, used butter crisco, half ww flour and 1/2 white flour, added 1 c wheat germ, 1 c old fashioned oats and a few heavy dashes of cinnamon.  Made 10 muffins along with my large loaf.  I added chocolate chips to the muffins only and now wish I had added them to the loaf as well.  Didnt have nay walnuts, still delish w/o them!  I also found I needed to lower my temp to 325.  About 20 minutes for the muffins and 65 mins for the loaf.

My husband and I love this recipe. I followed it exactly, but instead of dividing the batter into two loaf pans, I poured it into my Breadman and used the "batter bread" setting. Since there was a lot of volume, the Breadman didn't mix it too well, but I had already mixed the batter (including adding the nuts) before pouring it in. When it was done, the center had caved in and I was expecting raw batter and a flop of an idea,  but the loaf was wonderful. It was dense and very moist. I will definitely use the Breadman to make this tasty banana bread!

I wanted a new recipe and saw this.  
Of course all good cooks modify their recipes (laughing).  My major modification was putting on my Great Grandmother's apron because I needed help!  I didn't have the butter at room temp and it was a mess!  As soon as I put on the apron - I think my Great Grandmother took over.  

First, I only had 3 ripe bananas so I 1/2'd the recipe and used 3 mini loaf pans.

I also did the recommended:   1/2 brown 1/2 white sugars, 3/4 tsp. vanilla, and 3/4 cup of chopped walnuts.  Now for the kicker - I had bought a bag of culinary lavender sugar and sprinkled that on top of the batter before baking.  I took a photo but I do not see anything here about inserting a photo.  They are BEAUTIFUL!  Smell is wonderful, and I can't wait to cut into it.  

Thank you for sharing this recipe - I printed it and quickly hand-wrote in the modifications that I made so I can repeat it.

text:
DELICIOUS!! I modified the ingredients and followed the directions from a review submitted by "Virginia Sista"  Follow these directions and modifications--You are bound to have the perfect batch!! --CREAM butter and sugar, ADD eggs, one at a time, mixing after each addition, MIX in mashed banana, MIX in DRY ingredients to WET in three batches, scraping down after each, STIR in nuts. It makes no sense and serves no purpose that I can see to *stir* in banana, eggs or dry ingredients. They need *mixing* to be thoroughly incorporated. I added 1 tsp vanilla and 2 tsp cinnamon. Used dark brown sugar/white in a 3:1 ratio. Pecans instead of walnuts.

Very sweet, dense and awesome!


6-4-11  Making this again this morning for my family home for the 4th...so easy to make but I prefer just to cream the liquids then add all the dry and let it mix well in my stand alone mixer...so awesome I'll be making it for the holidays.

ETA:  I went to make this again this morning and started creaming my ingredients only to find I only had two bananas...so I took the author at her word and used the two I had and substituted 10 oz. of store bought Fugi Apple preserves (it's all I had!!) and reduced the white sugar by 1 cup.  I honestly thought that I was crazy to try this but it made the best muffins EVER!!!  I plan on using this as a base recipe for other jams...I'm thinking strawberry banana!!

I made this recipe twice.  First time as listed and I thought the baking time was too long and the bread was too flat. text:
This is EXCELLENT!!  Check bread at 55 minutes.  Mine was ready, and I"m glad I didn't leave it in for 5 or 10 more minutes (like I planned).  

Blend in ingredients slowly and one at time.  I recommend blending completely after you add each ingredient.  

I followed the recipe exactly, except that I added 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar.  
This is a keeper!

If you have trouble getting it to mix, have your kids use their CLEAN hands to do it.  My Grandma used to let me do this as a child and I loved it!  Do this when you make meatballs too.  Also, if you are having trouble with it rising, it is probably because the recipe omits baking POWDER.  Add a half teaspoon and that should do the trick.  Happy Thanksgiving!

I concur with Virgina Sista regarding the write up but if you are a baker the basics of creaming, mxing, folding always apply.    That being said the only modifications I made was splitting the sugar white/light brown.  I added 1 tsp of cream of tartar.  I increased the amount of walnuts by 1/2 cup since my family enjoys them. Thank you for posting it, you've earned 5 stars from this household!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Read all reviews and used most ... this is excellent and so moist ... changes made were sugar 1 cup white 1 cup brown, added 1 tsp ea. vanilla, cinnamon and baking powder, set oven at 325 and baked for 65 minutes.  I used my KitchenAide blender with whip hook to cream sugar and butter then added the vanilla and cinnamon, next went in the room temp eggs ...changed to mix hook then added bananas (used 6 that I had frozen after ripening, thawed then mashed).  Sift remaining dry ingredients and added slowly to wet mixture. I used Bakers Joy to spray on my 2 pyrex loaf pans. Afer baking for 50 minutes I checked on the little jewels then let go for another 12 to 15 minutes.  Could not wait for it to cool .... by far the best one I ever ate!

text:
Wonderful Recipe! Get compliments every time! Super moist and not too sweet. I'm asian and most American recipes seem to be just too sweet for the asian palate. This recipe is just nice.  I did add 1/2 tsp baking powder and substituted walnuts with pecans. I also baked it in pyrex loaf pans that are 8.5" x 4.5" to give it a more "breadish" dimension, instead of having it look too flat. Baked it a few times at different temperature and realized that when it is a little on the burnt side, it tastes better... so I just stuck with 350 F at 60 minutes... just nice!  Try it! You won't be sorry you used this recipe!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
followed the recommendations in Virginia Sista's review, and it was great!!  halved the recipe to just make one loaf, didn't add any nuts.  the crust on this is AMAZING!  buttery and brown!!  might have been since I only baked one loaf, but it only needed to bake about 55 minutes.

update 10/17 - I still love this recipe, it is my go to!  I have made my own variation.  First, I always use Kerrygold salted butter, the best, and second I use all brown sugar, no white (I always do this with cookie recipes too).  I love to rub the loaf pan with extra butter, then toss in 1 tablespoon white sugar and 1 teaspoon cinnamon, and coat the pan with that.  Gives the bread a great buttery crust!  Also, I always buy fresh cranberries in the fall, and keep a bag in my freezer, and this bread is so good loaded with fresh cranberries!  They burst while baking, and you have these little tart bits running through the sweet bread!

text:
This one turned out AWESOME!!! I couldn't help but add a little extra banana. With mixing the dry/wet, I putmy Kitchenaid mixer on low, and slowly added the dry to the wet. It leaves no dry clumps and always leaves an even mixture. If you add wet to dry, the wet will encompass the dry, resulting in clumps.

text:
Recipe is great BUT I oly had 3 riped bananas so I had to get creative. I took a can of pinneaple chunks and crushed them in food processor. Wao at 1st I was not sure but it came out great because the pinneapple made it nice and moist and you couldn't taste the pinneaple at all, it just helped with texture. I also added 1 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and 1 tsp of nutmeg. I did 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup of white sugar.  The color and texture were beautiful, nothing like the recipe picture. Enjoy, I highly recomend this recipe. ooh before I forget, I roasted the walnuts and I think gave it a nice flavor.

text:
This was pretty good, but defiantly lacking in flavor. If I were to make this again I'd add vanilla extract and cinnamon.  The directions are a little strange too. I suppose it would turn out okay if made as written but I creamed the butter and sugar until light and fluffy, added the eggs until well incorporated and stirred in the bananas (I didn't use nuts). Sift all the dry ingredients together, and add it in about 3 batches to the banana mixture. It came out fluffy and moist with a crusty top but not very flavorful.

text:
This recipe would have 5 stars if the review were based on taste alone.  Wow - the flavor of this banana bread is fantastic!!  After reading the reviews, I tweaked the recipe by adding 1/2 tsp of Baking powder, 1 tsp vanilla and exchanging 1 cup of the granulated sugar for dark brown.  Unfortunately, the center of my bread sank like the Titanic!  It was only about 3/4" thick in the center!  I have no idea why it would sink with the addition of the baking powder; I was thinking that should keep any of the rising problems at bay.  Anyway - if you don't mind possibly having funny looking bread, the taste is impeccable.  Give it a try!

text:
This was so good!  Thank you for such a great recipe.  I made some other changes as recommended by other reviewers.  I added 1 tso vanilla to wet ingredients, and added 1 tsp baking powder and 2 tsp cinnamon to the dry. Also used 1 cup packed brown sugar and only 1/2 cup white, for a total of 1 1/2 cups sugar.  I thought it was plenty sweet enough.  I creamed the butter and sugar, then added eggs one at a time, mixing after each.  Then I mixed in the mashed banana, and after that added the dry ingredients to the wet in three batches, scraping the sides after each.  I didn't use nuts, had none, and cooked for 45 minutes and it was perfect.    It was darker than in the picture, but did not affect the flavor at all.  AWESOME!!

text:
I have made this bread several times.  I've used the variations suggested by other reviewers and I've made it exactly as the recipe calls for.  This recipe is great no matter what you do.  I always do the one bowl method though - I use my stand mixer and cream the butter and sugar, then add the eggs one at a time, then the bananas, then the dry ingredients and finally the nuts.  Depending on humidity and altitude and whether I use brown sugar or not the cooking time varies from 45-70 minutes.  This bread makes a great gift if you have mini loaf pans.  I always get rave reviews and requests for the recipe.  This one is truly awesome and deserves more than 5 stars!!

text:
After an extensive search through old family cookbooks,popular classic cookbooks, and the internet, I finally came across the perfect recipe for banana nut bread. Just scanning the list of ingredients made my spirits soar; I was sure that I was looking at a recipe that would yield the heavy, moist banana nut bread that I so longed for. I'm delighted to say that I was right. I've made this banana nut bread on four occassions and it came out perfectly each time. I baked it most recently in a bundt pan for 45 minutes(no change in temperature), my husband commented that this one was the best I had ever made. ABSOLUTELY WONDERFUL!!!

text:
I really hope someone reads this and it helps them because I ruined my first batch!  I set the timer for 55 and checked it every 5 minutes after that it took about 62 minutes to be perfect. You also need to add only HALF the salt (even less if you use salted butter) it asks for - it tasted salty as a potato chip! I used 2 medium-large bananas and they measured out to be one cup mashed. If you add too much banana you will get a funny texture and it doesn't cook in the middle. I am sticking with this revised recipe because it makes a super buttery, moist and delicious banana bread :)

This is to die for! I make this all the time, with slight changes; I use 1/2 brown sugar and add loads of cinnamon and vanilla, plus some nutmeg. I also make a topping out of brown sugar, flour, butter, cinnamon and oatmeal, which really gives a nice crunch. EVERYONE loves this, even the picky kids. Stays good for days and freezes well - that is, if you manage to hide it. Absolutely delicious. Thank you!

text:
Yum!  This recipe is a definite keeper.  I never use nuts in my bread recipes, so I planned to substitute chocolate chips, but I made some without the chocolate chips just to see what it was like.  To my amazement, I actually prefer it without the chocolate (and I'm a die-hard chocolate lover)!  This bread tastes so good on its own that the chocolate just seems to interfere with the taste.  It has a very moist and buttery texture that I love (although it serves as a constant reminder of how unhealthy this stuff is).  After reading the reviews, I added a little vanilla (which probably didn't make much difference) and started checking for doneness after about 45 minutes in the oven (it was done a little early).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took the advice of many of the reviewers and made a few changes to this recipe. I added a generous teaspoon on vanilla, some chocolate chips in one loaf and a few dashes of cinnamon. I also cut the sugar down to 1-1/2 cups and mixed half white and half brown sugar. I inadvertantly used only half the butter that the recipe called for and it came out great. It does appear very dark but don't let that cause you to take it out early. One loaf cooked in 50 mins and the other with the chocolate chips cooked in 55 mins. It seems like a versatile enough recipe that you can change things to your liking without messing it up. It was still plenty sweet with less sugar. I think any more sugar would make it  unappealingly sweet for our tastes. And definately wait for it to cool for maximum taste. Happy baking!

text:
Its very yummy! I tried to make it a little body friendly. I subsitute half cup of butter with a fine grated apple (looks about half cup). Used 1/2 cup white sugar, 1/2 cup brown sugar and 7 packets of splenda (I don't like things too sweet). 3 eggs, yolks go in first. Whipped the white seperately till medium peak and fold in the batter. Added a dash of cinnamon and vanilla. Grabbed a handful of walnuts, chocolate chips and shredded coconuts. Unfortunately my husband only left me 2 large banana to work with, it yielded about 1 cup plus little more. Couldnt find my 9x5s used a bundt pan instead. Took me 1 hr and 30 mins to fully cook it.Extra bananas would definately be better.I gotta say... this is soooooo moist, not oily.  My friends literally inhaled it!!

This was a very tasty banana bread that can still turn out great even with a few small adjustments. Since I only had 2 and a half bananas, I halved the recipe so I'd have enough banana flavor. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This really is the most delicious banana nut bread I've ever made.  I've made this recipe several times using butter flavored crisco instead of butter, but I just made it using real butter, and that makes all the difference.  Also, I add 1/2 teaspoon of baking powder, 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract, and a little more banana and walnuts than the original recipe calls for.  I sprinkle the tops of mine with granulated sugar and pecans, and I only bake it for about 56 minutes.  I don't bother creaming my butter and sugar together, I just sift all the dry ingredients together and then fold the wet into the dry, and this seems to work really well.  I hope my tips help!  Good luck baking!

I've made this several times. I've made it exactly like the recipe but I've also made adjustments over time. I add vanilla extract, cinnamon and a pinch of nutmeg. I omit the nuts and add dark chocolate chips instead. Also, I do not sift the dry ingredients. I add the dry ingredients to the wet in batches. It's always so good and doesn't stay around long.

country:

text:
I have made it three times.  The best was the last but ALL were excellent.  The first making, I used the larger 9X5 loaf pans.  The edges were too brown when the center was done.  The last making I used three 8X4 loaf pans.  They were done after 30 minutes with the center done.  The crust was lighter, the bread moister and tastier.  This is more of an adaptation to my  oven than a critique of the recipe as all three makings were short lived and delicious!
I did alter the procedure a little but did not change the mouth or the taste.  As a cake maker, I cream the butter and sugar, add the eggs, walnuts and mashed bananas.  Lastly, I added the sifted dry ingredients.  This doesn't change the taste at all but made the texture less coarse with about the same density.  I do think this prevents the dry flour lumps another rather mentioned.
Again, I am very pleased with all makings.

text:
a few changes to this, but its great as is. I use whole wheat flour for about a third of the total flour listed.  i also cream the butter and sugar before mixing in the rest of the wet ingredients. then slowly add the dry to the wet in batches stirring completely before each dry batch and making sure no clumps. i've always been taught to add the dry to the wet. it makes for a better consistency and rise.

text:
My first time making this and it turned out perfect.  I mixed the dry ingredients in a bowl, adding 1 teaspoon of baking powder, and the rest I mixed in the food processor, using 4 bananas and 3 eggs.(all I had)..  I slowly added the dry ingredients into the wet and it was all mixed so quickly and easily.  Baked 50-55 min.  The dark color may make you think its overcooked but it comes out perfect.  I froze one loaf and had to take it out a couple weeks later, it was so moist and fresh tasting still.  .

The only change I made was using 1 tsp. baking soda instead of 2 tsp. otherwise, it falls in the middle. This change works for both high altitude and sea level.  It's the best, hands down, no questions asked banana bread recipe there is. I'm giving this recipe again, and again to people that I have baked for. Super easy and makes me feel like a real culinary genius! Haha... If they only knew how incredibly simple this is. Also, whenever I make this banana bread, I make about a dozen loaves and they never last more than 2 days! Crazy Good and Even more crazy that we can eat that much! FABULOUS! The only change I made was 1/2 tsp baking powder, 1 1/2 cups white sugar and `/2 cup brown sugar. Oven set at 325 to start and then halfway through, upped it to 350. Used pecans and baked for 55 minutes. This bread is NOT a high riser, so check after an hour with a cake tester.

text:
This recipe is described as a "very flexible" recipe, but it did not take well to baking in muffin tins for 20-25 minutes like most banana bread recipes do. If I had watched the video tips and noticed how very little rise this recipe has, I would not have tried it. The muffins actually sank into the tins!  The bottom of each muffin stuck to the tins despite greasing and flouring the tins. And the flavor that everyone is madly raving about? Salt and sugar. This is a very salty, cloyingly sweet banana nut bread. It was moist, and had a nice crunch to the top - for that, the recipe gets two stars. Otherwise it was a waste of good ingredients and I would not bake it again.

text:
Awesome! I had some over ripe bananas that I didn't want to throw away, so I went looking for a recipe and found this little gem.  After reading the reviews, I cut the butter to 3/4 cup, and added a tsp each of cinnamon, baking powder, and nutmeg, and about a tsp and a half of vanilla. I couldn't help but add a few shakes of pumpkin pie and apple pie spice. I also substituted pecans for walnuts (since I didn't have any walnuts), and added raisins. It made enough for 24 muffins. I used 1 cup of white sugar, a 1/2 cup light brown sugar, and a 1/2 cup of dark brown sugar. I baked at 325 for 30-35 minutes. Like many others, mine didn't rise much, but the texture and flavor was perfect. I may add more baking powder next for more rise, but they are super yummy. Will make again! Thanks, OP, for a great recipe! :)

Loved this recipe. So moist! Good foundation. I added 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp nutmeg and 1/4 cup oatmeal. I split the sugars 1 cup brown, one cup white, because I was short on white sugar. I cut the oven heat to 300 degrees. And baked for 55 minutes.

text:
I've never had a bad banana bread and this was okay. Definitely not the best I've ever had.
I am a bit confused at most of the low ratings. I am not a baker but I never encountered the issues many were having. The bread wasn't flat. It was a bit greasier than I was used to but nothing off-putting. I used half white, half brown sugar and the bread did turn out really dark, but I don't see how that is a problem. It's not like it was burned. I like the sweetness. The edges were even good, almost caramelized.
I did think it lacked some flavor. Some of this would have been better if I had had the whole 1 cup of walnuts (the best part of any banana bread), but I was surprised that there weren't any spices in this recipe. I have never made a banana bread so I wasn't sure. One thing for sure, this bread requires no butter on it.
So, it's a good eat but I think I will try and get my stepmother's recipe if I make banana bread in the future.

Gluten-Free works! I used Bob's Red Mill All Purpose G-F Flour in the same quantity as called for here, and it worked well.  I am always working to reduce sugar; used Agave Nectar and 1/2 the quantity -- 1 cup. Loved it.  Am going to incorporate 1 tsp. baking powder next time as my loaves do not rise very much. The ebnb i have made wiyhout the baking powder fits nicely into one loaf pan. This recipe is excellent! And because it works well with G-F flour, i, too, can enjoy it with my family.  Oh, and I use Earth Balance dairy-free, soy-free "butter" as i have dairy allergies as well. It works! Thank You for a great recipe.

text:
Ok, so I couldn't find my "Nanny's recipe for banana nut bread so I went looking for a temporary replacement, hoping to find hers someother time. WOW... I've made it 3 times I believe and its a huge hit! I've made it with butter and oil both delicious! Made it with white and Brown sugar still delicious! Accidentally added 2 cups of nuts the first time I made it and it became my twist because my family went "nuts" for the nuts! Added an extra 1/4 cup of bananas cause that's what I had when I was done mashing most certainly still delicious! One time I was 1/2 cup short of ripe banana so added 1/2 apple sauce and you couldn't even tell, gotta love a recipe that's this flexible. Bread looked pretty dark when it was done but it was not burnt. The top was a little crispy but again was not burnt, I even enjoyed the texture change... However If u don't care for the crisp top, wrap it in plastic for a few hours if u can manage to wait that long. I still hope to find "Nanny's" recipe in her writing for heirloom reasons but this is the only banana nut bread recipe I need!

text:
After searching the internet for a new banana nut bread recipe,and after eagerly reading most of the reviews, I decided  try this one. I added a tsp of baking powder and a tsp of vanilla as others had suggested and used 1/2 white and 1/2 brown sugar. I also decreased the oven temp to 325 instead of 350. I cooked it for exactly 50 minutes and it was done. The taste is very good. It is moist and not dry at all. I am a little disappointed as I was looking for a more dense version and this is not as dense as I was led to believe. I would consider the texture and sweetness of this bread to be more like that of a "cake" than a bread. Over all, it is good, and was easy to make. It just wasn't exactly what I was looking for.

I made this two days ago and used one cup white sugar and one cup brown sugar and also added vanilla and cinnamon.  I also mixed my ingredients differently from the directions -- used a mixer to cream the butter and sugars; then added eggs, dry ingredients, and mashed bananas; lastly stirred in chopped nuts. text:
I am not a baker like my Grandma, who has perfected peanut brittle, ginger snaps, pumpkin roll and chocolate sheet cake to name a few!  I only had 2 round pie pans and I did half the batch without walnuts for my baby boy.  I used a whole cup of walnuts in just half the batter and it was perfect for us because we like it nutty!  4 large bananas mashed down to 2 cups.  Warning, do not add butter to your piece after baking, this recipe makes it so you don't need to!!!  I ate a piece fresh after baking, it was delicious!  My edges did end up too brown, but I assumed this would happen.  I have made this before with loaf pans and it was perfect then, too!  Do refrigerate to keep fresh, I did not and it made a difference.

text:
OMG This is the BEST banana nut bread ever. I am not a banana nut bread lover but I had two large bananas that were too ripe to just peel and eat. I found this recipe and and tried it because of all the wonderful reviews. The only thing I added that wasn't in the recipe was 1t vanilla,1t cinnamon and used pecans instead of walnuts. I halved the recipe for I only had 2 bananas which when mashed was a heaping cup full. I foiled lined a bread pan(mine are old)and baked the bread for 55 minutes. I cannot describe how good this tasted, even for me. I WILL be baking a lot more of these breads in the future. It baked perfectly. You must try this recipe, you will not be disappointed. Thank you very much, saseigel. You did good!!!!

text:
Will definitely be using this as a starter to my banana mut breads.  I reduced the recipe to make one loaf instead of two and it came out perfectly.  There were a couple of changes I made, that I will remember for next time: (1) I didn't bake for the 60-70 minutes but more like 40-50 (2) I used half white sugar and half light brown sugar (3) I like surprises in my banana breads, so I throw in an extra ingredient or two.  This time I made blueberry banana nut bread.  Next time, I will try adding coconut and pineapple, nutella or chocolate chips, or even pumpkin and spices for a fall version.  Message me if you have any other ideas!

Really great start to a banana recipe.  Definitely easy to follow!  Thanks!

Great recipe! Easy, yummy, I was so impressed I made it twice in one week! (because I, and my family, ate all of it so fast!). Here's the kicker - I burnt the bottom! I only had to cook mine for 30 minutes - I used a glass 9x13 casserole dish - as I didn't have a loaf pan handy. This change in dish altered the cooking time. Even though the bottom of the bread was 'slightly blackened' - I just sliced it off and served the perfectly uber moist, delicious remainder of the bread. It was /so/ good, that we didn't mind eating around the over toasted part. It's a keeper! Even burnt! Hah!

city:

country:
None
text:
This banana bread was certainly tasty, but I don't think there's any reason to be so hysterical about it.  I tried this both warm and chilled; I think you can taste the banana better when it's cold. 

As an adult, I'm used to reduced-fat baking.  This bread tasted much like the kind of bread my family used to make when I was growing up.  So, again, it certainly was tasty, but the way the recipe is written you'd think SWAT teams would bust through my windows the second I cut it!! :)  

I added 1 tsp. each vanilla and cinnamon, though I didn't explicitly taste them in the finished product.  I baked for 60 minutes total (checking after 45 minutes) and needed to tent with foil because by 45 minutes the top was more than browned enough.

text:
As other reviewers noted, this bread does not rise -- but it won't matter once you take a bite! YUM.  I did change the recipe a bit:  instead of white flour, I used 1 1/3 cups whole wheat & 2/3 cups quick oats; I used 1 cup white & 1 cup brown sugar, & added 1/2 t baking powder, 1 t vanilla & 1 t cinnamon.  Oh - also, used 1/2 cup butter & 1/2 a cup apple sauce instead of 1 cup butter.  Baked 4 small loaves for about 45-50 mins, and the leftover batter as mini-muffins for about 18 mins.  Also, sprinkled brown sugar & oats over the tops.

Display Name:
XLBrooklyn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With moderate additions and substitutions, this has become a Saturday-night-only treat - cuz you gotta go to confession in the morning!

Like other people do:
add 1/2 tsp baking powder (total 2 1/2 tsp)
add 1 tsp cinnamon

Also:
add 1 tsp vanilla
add 2 tbs black rum (Goslings, etc)

Eggs: do not use 4 jumbo - use AA size.  If Jumbo, use only 3.

I pour into one single loaf pan and add 15 minutes baking time (total 75 minutes).

Great by itself.  Also good:  toasted with orange marmalade or cream cheese on top.  OR: Thinly sliced and layered with bannana cream pudding to make a sort-of torte.  Top with rum-laced whipped cream.  Chill couple hours before serving.

None
text:
This is the real deal folks.  A great banana nut loaf, requiring very few tweaks to make perfect.  I added 1tsp Vanilla Extract and it made the flavor perfect.  I also used my Kitchenaid mixer to incorporate all the ingredients.  It was just too difficult to do it by hand and I ended up with some unincorporated lumps of dry ingredients.  Put it in a mixer and let it do the work.  In any case, perfect flavor, perfect consistency and great moisture.  I would also be sure to watch cooking times closely.  The 1hr10min timeframe is way too long.  Mine were done in about 35 minutes.  Of course, that is probably dependent on the type of oven you have, but that was my experience.

text:
Great stuff! A big hit with me & my guys.  Followed the ingredient list almost exactly, except added 1 tsp vanilla extract and 1/8 tsp nutmeg.  Followed another reviewer's recommendation to assemble more traditionally:  cream butter & sugar, add eggs & vanilla & mix well, add dry ingredients 1/3 at a time, then fold in nuts.  Did not have loaf pans, so I made 12 cupcakes, baked 35 minutes and one 9" square pan, also baked 35 minutes. This one is a keeper!

text:
I'm a chef at a major university. This is a recipe I've made many times and have it memorized since it is the best banana bread recipe out there. I usually make it as a cake, using half white and half brown sugar, pecans and chocolate chips and I make a sweetened cream cheese icing to go with it. The icing I make tastes more like cream cheese than frosting so its not too sweet. I made the cake for some of my co-workers (others chefs and cooks)and everyone who tried it said it was the best banana anything they've ever had. One woman said she even dreamed about it that night and people talked about it all week. This is the perfect banana bread.

AMAZING recipe! My boyfriend and I could not stop eating the bread! Just as a note, 2 cups of mashed bananas is about 4 med-lar bananas. I would also say depending on how hot your oven gets, check the bread about 50 minutes into cooking. My oven gets extra hot, so it was done after about 55 minutes. It was actually a little overdone, but I LOVED the crunchy outside. This is going in the recipe box. I definitely will be making it again. I am actually looking forward to when my bananas over-ripen. I will not be throwing away any more! :)

Rating:

helpfulCount:

userID:
4372433
Display Name:
michellecammack
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
9
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe, though I did change it up quite a bit based on other reviews.  I found the perfect baking time for me was 335 for 55 minutes.  If you want a slightly darker crust do it for 60 minutes.  In addition, I use 3/4 cups of white sugar and 3/4 cups of brown sugar.  Using 2 full cups was way too sweet for me.  I use 5-6 medium bananas.  Add 1 tsp of cinnamon and 1tsp vanilla.  I also add 1 1/2 tsp baking powder and 1tsp baking soda.  Helps the bread rise.  I also only use 1/2-3/4 cup of butter instead of the full cup.  Again, just preference.
Great foundation for the recipe, just needed a little tweaking.

text:
O.k., I panicked. When I mixed everything it was real runny. So I added a scoop of flour, remembered a reviewer said they added baking powder. So I ended up putting in probaly a half cup more of flour, a small teaspoon of powder. I also added mexican vanilla. (My family's secret ingredient in everything!) I have one pan the size it called for, but I have two in glass. I hate cooking in glass, always turns out weird. But they were a gift from my sister so it's what I had! The loaves look REAL dark, but were not done in the middle. So I turned it down to 325* and baked them for 10 min more. I have yet to taste the finshed product, will update when I do! Smell gooooood! Batter was yummy too.

text:
EXCELLENT!! I like others used 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup light brown sugar, 1tsp cinnamon and 1tsp vanilla. FYI the brown sugar makes it look extra brown but it was cooked to perfection in 55 min. Just in case you're wondering like I was, 2 cups banana is about 4 whole bananas. I actually didn't even notice that it said 2 CUPS banana until after I baked it. I only used 2 whole bananas and while it was delicious this way it was even better with 2 more bananas.  I used pecans instead of walnuts. This is by far the most delicious EBNB I've ever had!!

text:
I just made the best banana muffins of my life I think!  I will say I tweaked it a bit for what I had, but I think these would be great just as written. my main changes were that I used half butter flavored shortening and half sour cream for the fat, added a bit of vanilla, 3/4c white sugar & 3/4c dark brown, I added 1t baking powder.  I started with the eggs, added the sugars, shortening sour cream, then added the bananas without mashing, vanilla and then the dry ingredients and finally the nuts, all in my mixer, in that order and they came out yummy!  oh, and I cooked the muffins at 400 degrees for 15-18 min.  (and a real yummer that some in my family didn't even notice, but I thought was delicious- in one pan I mixed in a bit of rhubarb that I had diced, sugared and microwaved for a minute or so.  mmmmm.....)

text:
Tip number 1 in the footnotes section is SERIOUSLY invaluable advice. The bread is still on the cooling rack, but there is now only half a loaf left seeing as I'm trying to get work done in my kitchen, but the EBNB keeps beconing me to eat it! Supposedly it's better tomorrow, I just hope it lasts that long!  Absolutely awesome! Moist, banana nut perfection.  I made the following adjustments:  reduced to 12 servings ghee instead of butter 1 tbsp. vanilla 1/2 cup dark brown sugar 1/2 cup white sugar 2 cup banana 3/4 cup white flour 1/4 cup wheat flour 2/3 cup chopped walnut 5 tbsp. flax seeds  bake at 350 for 65 minutes  Also, I followed Virginia Sista's mixing instructions.  There's going to be a little banana bread competition later at my boyfriend's house, and I'm going into it pretty confident.

country:
None
text:
I love banana nut bread, but this is the first one I have  ever made.  I had several browned bananas that needed to be used.  I made 2 changes.  The first change was to follow several of the other comments and used one cup white sugar and one cup dark brown sugar.  My second change is that I did not have any baking soda so I used SELF-RISING FLOUR.  It made the bread a little lighter and fluffier, but not too much.  If you like more dense BNB then use the all-purpose flour.  The bread is very good, but I think it could use a little more flavor.  I will make this recipe again and use more bananas and either cinnamon or all spice like others have suggested.

This is a wonderful recipe! This recipe actually lived up to it's description! The only thing I changed was the sugar. I used 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup Light brown sugar. I like other reviewers used 2tsp cinnamon and 1 tsp vanilla, but also added a snack size box of raisins as this is how I grew up on Banana nut bread. It only took 55 min to bake, I used smaller loaf pans and got three loafs out of this recipe. If you have a newer oven definitely check on your BNB at the 55min mark. I love this recipe and can not wait to share it with friends and family, or maybe not. :>

Display Name:
antonios_girl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out great.  I did make a couple of changes.  I used whole wheat flour instead of all purpose and did a 3:1 ratio of brown and white sugar.  These gave the bread a nice darker color.  I also added a teaspoon of vanilla extract to the wet ingredients and 3/4 cup of oatmeal to the dry mix.  I reduced the amount of baking soda to just 1 teaspoon because I like a slightly denser bread.  That is just personal preference.  I baked the loaves only about 50-55 minutes, but that is something that you have to gauge yourself.  I would start checking after 45 minutes so that you don't overbake it.  It turned out great.  The oats and the nuts gave it a nice crunchiness.  This was my first time making banana nut bread.  I will definitely use this recipe again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This banana bread was very tasty, I added just slightly more than 2 cups banana's. And oddly enough, I only made one loaf with this recipe, one normal sized loaf. So I wouldn't say that it makes two unless they're really tiny.  OH and I did a little research amd found that baking soda shouldn't be used in recipes that require long bake times because the chemical reaction that occurs when you use b. soda happens immediately after you add it so it must be cooked quickly. That could be why some people report unleavened breads. At the same time that could be what helps the density of this bread, i would add that extra tsp of baking powder, or even substitute one tsp of soda for powder.
