This Banana Bread is AMAZING. The only things that I like to add are 1tsp Vanilla extract, & a dash of nutmeg, ground cloves & cinnamon.   The only reason I coudln't give this 5 stars is because the baking times are WAY off. I've made this more than once, and it only needs 45 minutes to bake. My oven is quite accurate & thankfully I thought to check this before the 60 minutes had passed or they would have been burnt for sure.... so beware of over cooking the loafs!  Other than that though, this recipe is FABULOUS & one I plan to use over & over again.

I was really disappointed in this recipe after the great reviews.  First, it did not rise right.  I made muffins and the batter spread all over then sank in the middle.  I do live at high altitude, so that may be part of the problem.  Also, the butter taste was overwhelming.  Other people commented on this, and I thought, how can a butter taste be bad?  Well, now I know.  I felt like I was eating a greasy butter muffin instead of a moist banana muffin.  I won't be making this recipe again.

text:
A little patience goes a long way with this recipe. With my gas oven it takes about an hour to bake. I cut down on the baking soda, which keeps it a little more dense. Which is the way I like it. Be careful though, DO NOT use the very course coffee sugar, unless you like your bread a little crunchy. If you want to try something different with this recipe, try these two things. 1) don't mash the bananas, just slice them and add them as you mix it all up. 2) Add a teaspoon of ground nutmeg. Believe me, it takes it to a whole new level.

text:
Real Crowd pleaser!
I added the 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp vanilla and 1 tsp baking powder suggested by others,substituted a cup of brown sugar for the white sugar and used 2 whole eggs and 2 egg whites.  I would also suggest if you want non-dairy, super moist bread, use half a cup of oil (I used olive) and half a cup of applesauce (I used natural, but sweetened works too).  It may take a few extra minutes to bake, but the bread doesn't dry out as much.

text:
Out of the many banana bread recipe that I've used in the past, this one takes the cake.  It was by far the most flavorful and delicious.  I substituted one cup of white sugar for brown sugar, added a tsp of vanilla extract, and used pecans instead of walnuts because I didn't have any.  I also used a bundt cake pan instead of bread pans which worked great, I just reduced the temperature of the oven a little and kept it in for 10-15 minutes longer, keeping an eye on it.  I just made this yesterday and already it's almost gone.  It toasts in the toaster beautifully but is just as good untoasted.  Excellent banana bread!!

I was not a huge fan of Banana Nut Bread, but I had ripe bananas and did not want to throw them out. I will definitely make this bread again.  The texture is wonderful. I can't wait to make this again!

text:
Oh My Gosh! This is the absolute best and I have been making banana nut bread for over 50 years. It's nice that the recipe makes two loaves. As long as the oven is on for 1 hour, might as well make two. My bread is a bit on the dark side, which is fine as the bananas were tossed into the freezer with the peels on for a few weeks. I also used 2 cups of walnuts. 1 cup of butter seemed like a lot so next time I will use 3/4 cup butter and 1/4 cup apple butter. The texture was perfectly moist, firm and baked in the exact time suggested. I did line the bread pans with waxed paper which allowed for easy removal. Nice large loaves too.

I've only made banana nut bread once before and it pales in comparison to this recipe. I followed the recipe almost exactly, but I added 1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/2 tsp vanilla butter and nut flavor and cinnamon. I also mixed eggs and butter separately, then added to all dry ingredients, then added mashed bananas and nuts last. It was FANTASTIC! My finicky 3 year old loved it and my 13 year old thought it was great too. Very moist, perfectly sweet...delicious. I will be making this again very soon!!!

text:
It is perfect! made it 3 times everytime...everyone loves it!

***Update.. I've made this soo many times. I find that by adding a pinch of baking powder and mixing this in without a mixer (yes by hand)and it comes out with the best texture...worth the extra work. I also seperate and beat the egg whites to fold in last. Also, if I feel that I want to cut down on the butteriness I cut the butter to 1/2c and use 1/2 of oil instead. I still love this recipe...and so does my roommate who is has a deathly irrational fear of bananas.. lol. He likes it so much that he asks me to make it but will refuses to acknowledge what its made of. Also, its always gone within a day or two.

To up the ante on this, instead of using flour to line the pan use a cinnamon/sugar mixture. Try it once and you'll never go back to flour again. OMG this is the absolute BEST!!!!! Every time I even suggest making this, people start coming out of the wood works asking for a loaf. I once had to make 20 loafs in one day (that was fun) and they were all gone in before they could cool. :) Very easy to make and ohhhh sooooo goooooood. If you want to fall in love with Banana Nut Bread make this one!!!!

text:
After reading reviews about this bread being too greasy, I used half butter and half applesauce.  It was still plenty rich.  I added some vanilla, used half brown and half white sugar, and also used half ww flour and half all purpose flour.  I made half of the recipe since I only had two bananas and made two mini loaves.  With one loaf, I added a generous handful of chopped pecans.  The loaf with and the laof without nuts were both very good.  My three small children loved it--I'll make it again!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5976006.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make banana bread a lot.  I have never really found a recipe that I can say "this is the best I have ever tasted!!"  I can now say I have found THE BANANA BREAD RECIPE.  I made sure my banana were near black.  I pureed them with my mixer.  My ingredients were at room temperature.  I made sure all my ingredients were well mixed like the recipe calls.  I dont like a dome on my bread so I only grease the bottoms of my pans.  This allows the bread to crawl up the sides.  I let the bread sit about 5 min after cooking time and assuring it was done, then I took a knife and made sure the bread was loose from the sides of the pan.  I let is completely cooled... Of course not before having several samples... Darn this was great banana bread and very easy to make.

text:
muy delicioso! Tweaked a few ingredients though...I added one jar of Gerbers Banana baby food I KID YOU NOT! they are perfect for banana bread because they are ripe and pureed..it made my bread so soft and moist (I was able to reduce the butter content by almost half because of this step. As well used half butter half shortening. Used half brown sugar half splenda/sugar mixture. Added 1/2 tsp extra salt to accentuate the buttery taste without having to add extra butter. Excellent recipe!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7045036.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
At first, I had reservations about this bread. I made it in a tube pan for my boyfriend's birthday. When I was done, it was still warm and had a slight burnt taste to the edges and it was a little undercooked on the bottom/top of the cake (it was a tube pan, so it was actually the bottom). It ended up cooking as it cooled, so that was fine.

It tasted much better at room temperature the next day, and even BETTER cold in the fridge on the third day!

The bread was moist and delicious.

I followed the advise of others here by adding a tsp vanilla, cinnamon, and half white, half brown(gourmet) sugar.

With no icing, this was a really good banana bread. Not the best I've had, but really good and I would make it several times again.

I also only baked it for about 45 Minutes.

text:
I am RE-RATING THIS RECIPE!! This is truley the best banana bread recipe.  I have tweaked t my way but the end result is awesome. I would like to share my tweaks; I make 3 loaves not 2. Here is my substitutions. I do use the 1 cup butter not marjarine. I still use 1/4C Mayonaise for extreme moisture. I do add however an additonal full cup of flour now. I add chunky applesauce 1 Cup 1 Tesp Cinnamon or allspice. No white sugar I always use 2 cups dark brown sugar. I also sometimes add chopped pecans about 1/2 cup and some occasions I mix in about 3/4 cup pf dired berry/cherry blend of dred fruit. What I love is that this s the best base recipe for doing your own thing it never goes wrong. Your moms recipe is indeen EBNB and I highly reccomend using this recipe. I just made 3 more loaves.

text:
If you love a dense banana bread this is the one for you! I've made this a few times and everyone loves it. I have made a few changes to suit my own tastes, I add about 1 tsp. of each vanilla extract, ground cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves. One morning I decided to make this when it was my turn to host playgroup at the last minute and I was out of walnuts, I threw in about a cup of raisins instead and it was very good that way also. Good alternative if you're not a nut person. Freezes well.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7144524.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make 2 batches and put in 3# aluminum loaf pans to freeze in 1 gallon freezer bags and give away or bring to work as needed..delicious recipe...for sure alway make it now at 1 hour and 10 minutes..it will look like its getting too brown but if you remove it based on color it will still be uncooked in the middle so at least 1 full hour at 350 and longer if in bigger pans.  The crust will seem overdone at first but soften..i like to sprinkle decorating sugar on top or turbinato for a crunchy fun topping.  This is a wonderful recipe.  But as with any baking soda quickbread you will learn how full to fill your pans and it gets better the 2nd time but deff stick with this!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I, too, made a few changes:

I used 2 teaspoons baking powder (as someone said, this is the right amount for 2 cups flour).
I used 1 cup sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar.
I used pecans instead of walnuts.
I used 2 teaspoons vanilla.
I used 1 teaspoon cinnamon. 
I added 1/4 cup dark coffee rum.

In my oven, 65 minutes was perfect! The bread is moist and delicious! Next time I will add more rum, I think.

Oops, almost forgot. My bananas weren't big enough, so 4 fell about 1/2 cup short, so I added 1/2 cup apple sauce.

This is obviously a very forgiving recipe!

text:
I didn't change a thing and this is AMAAAAAAZING. It is a bit on the sweet side, so you could probably cut half a cup of sugar and still have it be plenty sweet enough. I made a double batch and used slightly smaller toss away loaf pans, so I cooked it just a wee bit less,,,,,,,doubling the recipe gave me 5 of the smaller loaves. The loaves turned out nicely after 5 minutes of resting, no broken loaves :)  I cheated though,,,,,,,couldn't wait a few hours for it to cool and we ate it warm,,,,,omgosh, with real butter on top, FABULOUS.

text:
Before baking you should know that this recipe yields for TWO loaves!

I did not alter anything except how I added and mixed. 
For those who are not in the kitchen much, just use your stand mixer to cream the butter, eggs, and sugar.  Then add your dry ingredients, mix for about a minute or two on slow setting,  and fold in walnuts. 
Bake time as instructed (can vary depending upon altitude/oven).

text:
Just a note about HIGH ALTITUDE baking. I have used this recipe for years and I think it is definitely 5 star.  I use pecans and add a little cinnamon like some others on this sight.  Then, I moved to 8000 ft. Altitude and have a problem with sinking in the middle.  Be sure to add 2 Tablespoons more flour than the recipe and do not open the oven door until time to take it out.

I made this twice just to be sure  the second time is when I cut some batter for testing in my muffin pan. text:
Well, I found this recipe yesterday and I made it today at work for my coworkers.  We bring fruit to work and had some bananas too ripe to eat and a coworker said, hey, these would make great bread.  So...of course I had too.  It made the building smell yummy.  Perfect with cold front blowing in.  I did read most of the comments and I did tweak it a bit as most did.  I added vanilla, cinnamon and baking powder.  I also had never thought of doing what one said, grease pan and instead of flour coat with cinnamon sugar.  OMG!  This is by far the best banana bread recipe I have ever used.  So far, I have given two copies.  But I posted on FB, so more copies there.  Thank you.  Deliciousness!!! Have a wonderful blessed day!

Found my kin!  I made no changes. This was exactly like my grandmas!  I specifically searched for dense banana nut bread and found this recipe. I have tried to make many banana nut bread recipes before and they usually turn out like banana cake. For people not happy about it not rising, I would say that its not supposed to. The description at the beginning is completely on point. I thought my family would eat 1/2 of 1 loaf that day and then we would have 1 1/2 for other family members coming for dinner the next day.  Well that didnt exactly work out.  The footnotes at the end, (which I thought was an exaggeration) are absolutely true! This is perfect and has made my whole family happy!

None
country:
None
text:
OK.. definately a 5 star recipe.  But, as the author suggested, "use what you have on hand"...  so I did.  I didnt have any bananas but I did have 1/2 of a butternut squash , roasted and ready to go.  I pureed it and used it instead of mashed banana.  I added cinnamon, ginger and allspice as well.  2 tablespoons of homemade vanilla just because it is so yummy and 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar.  It turned out better than I could have hoped. It is a forgiving recipe as well.  I added way to much puree, maybe 2 1/2 cups because I didnt want it to go to waste  I think this means not only do I have a new "Go To" banana nut  bread recipe but also a new pumpkin bread recipe.

It makes no sense and serves no purpose that I can see to *stir* in STIR in nuts. It makes no sense and serves no purpose that I can see to *stir* in banana, eggs or dry ingredients. They need *mixing* to be thoroughly incorporated. I added 1 tsp vanilla and 2 tsp cinnamon. Used dark brown sugar/white in a 3:1 ratio. Pecans instead of walnuts. Have not tasted anything this great in a LOOOONG time! The crust is fabulous, banana flavor is great, moisture is awesome! And I read it will be better tomorrow!! Amazing.

I have used this recipe for about 5 years now. It really doesn't get any better than this, for a tasty dense banana bread. The 2 cups of banana is usually about 4 bananas, but for guaranteed denseness I go for about 6 bananas.

text:
I have made this a couple of times and it does not last long.  It is a very flexible recipe.  I used half white/half brown sugar.  The last time I made it I followed a suggestion that instead of greasing and flouring the pan, you grease (spray) the pan and coat it with cinnamon sugar.  It made the bottom sweet and crunchy.  Recipe is also perfect as written!

Made it 2x's because the first time was so good.  That means something coming from me, because I don't care for bananas!  I really don't like walnuts, and didn't have any on hand, so substituted the walnuts with Planter's pistachio/almond/cashew mix. Had to substitute because I ran out. Used a cup of margarine/oil.

Recipe great as is, just always tweaking things.

text:
A very good recipe.  I made some substitutions to 1 3/4 c 100% whole wheat flour, used pure unrefined organic coconut oil, cut down the sugar to 1 c brown + 1/2 c white sugar, added 2 tsp of real vanilla, 1 T of Ceylon (real) cinnamon, and added 3/4 cup of bittersweet chocolate chips.  Cooked it at 340 for 75 min.  It was perfect!  The boys next door said it was "bananalicious" lol.

This was sooo good. Followed advice of others added 1/2tsp baking powder, 2 tsp vanilla extract, used pecans instead of walnuts as the husband prefers pecans, and then did a butter crisco pan coating with  cinnamon sugar mix in place of the flour. Sent 2 loaves to work which received great feed back and a coveted its pretty good from the husband who can usually find a flaw or a reason to pick at a recipe. The seal of approval from the dog as well who kept trying to steal my bread anytime I turned away from my plate for a milisecond.  That being said. One of if not the best banana bread I have ever had and as such my new banana bread go to recipe. Thank you so much for posting it and thank you to the others as well who posted the modifications.

text:
I was in a hurry so I made this recipe as muffins; it made 3 dozen. The author was right, substitutions worked fine: I didnt have chopped nuts so I substituted 1/3 c hazelnut flour, 1/3 c flaxseed meal and added chocolate chips. I glazed them with a little brown sugar melted in hot coffee. They were quickly devoured by a group of hungry teens. My banana bread is always on the dry side, but these were super moist and springy. This is a keeper!

text:
This recipe came out way better than we expected but we did a few things different. The first thing we did was add a teaspoon of vanilla to the wet mix right before adding the dry mix in. We also used two 4x8 loaf pans instead and baked them at 350 for 50 minutes each. We will definitely be making it again. 

P.S. listen when it says to cool completely, wrap, and refrigerate for 2 hours. It was good warm but waking up this morning and trying it after it sat in the fridge tasted 10x better!

text:
Amazing banana nut bread recipe. I have been using this recipe for the last five years (I found it on here, but had not thought to review it until now).  Everyone that has tried it has commented on how good it tastes.  I follow the recipe exactly  as written. On occasion, I have omitted the walnuts (for friends who can't have nuts), with the same great results.  Once it cools, I wrap it in Saran Wrap and leave it on the counter.  It is great served the day it is baked, and is even better the next day! You can even freeze it, for up to one month, let it thaw at room temperature and serve it (still amazing)!

I did turn down my conventional oven to 325 and baked it for 55 minutes with the loaf in the metal pan and and 65 minutes with my stone pan.

text:
I made two changes to this recipe, and it was absolutely delicious! Instead of 2 cups of sugar, I used 1 & 1/2 cups of sugar. The banana bread was still very sweet and delicious.
The second change is actually more interesting, I substituted Pillsbury gluten-free flour for regular bread flour. If you didn't know it was gluten free it you wouldn't have known it by eating it. It was wonderful. As I have a good friend that's gluten-free, I thought we'd give it a try. Getting any kind of good bread is a real treat. She was thrilled. I will be posting this on a gluten-free baking website also.

text:
AllRecipes has never let me down!  And this recipe for banana bread was no exception.  I baked it not knowing what to expect. The only change or addition I made was after reading the many reviews, I added 1 tsp of cinnamon and 1tsp of vanilla.  I think the 1tsp of baking soda may have been a quite bit too much as the bread did not rise.  To cover this up, I cut and arranged the bread on a platter.  This bread is awesome! Everybody that tasted it, enjoyed it and while it lasted many came back for seconds.  Its amazing, moist and I love it. I will be making it again, and again!  Thank you for sharing your recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I made this two ways, as written (for ingredients) but I incorporated the dry ingredients into the wet in a stand mixer which was excellent and gluten and dairy free which I loved! I used 1 1/2cups 1:1 Bob's Red Mill gluten free flour(at Whole Foods) and 1/2 cup almond meal and coconut oil in place of the  butter and it came out delicious. I also added a 1/2 cup of dark chocolate Guittard chocolate chips (happens to be dairy free) and nearly a cup walnuts. My kids love this as well!! Great recipe. It baked in 50 minutes at 350 for me.

text:
Well, not quite sure how to rate this one. I added vanilla and substituted pecans for the walnuts (I'm a self-respecting southern gal, after all).  Checked the oven at 54 minutes and both loaves were flat and burned. Toothpick tested done. Took them out in disgust, since this was to be the desert I'm taking to a Christmas party. Started writing a 1 star review, but then I sliced and tasted. Delicious, in spite of being burned.  So....... 1 star for appearance and recipe trustworthiness (because the specified cooking time would have yielded something that looks like charcoal) and 5 stars for taste.

text:
I've been using this recipe for several years and I love it. I added 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1 1/2 tsp nutmeg, and 1 tsp allspice. I used nearly 2 cups of pecans instead of walnuts. I also did things a bit differently by first beating the bananas until they were completely smooth. Then I creamed the butter and sugar and added the eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. I baked it for 55 minutes, then took it out, checked it, covered with foil, and baked for another 15 minutes.

This is not a bad recipe, but it needs some help, IMO.  First I cut back the sugar by half a cup. I also doubled the walnuts.  I added a quarter tsp of vanilla and half a tsp of ground cardamom. As written though, it's a bit bland for my tastes, but it is really moist and it has a nice crumb.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, I can't say I wasn't warned..... the submitter of this recipe gave a health warning.  I made no changes to this recipe and after having a slice I had heartburn for over an hour.  There is just too much butter in the recipe, too much isn't better.....it's just too much!  When I inverted the pans to put the loaves on a rack, my hands were greasy with butter.  I do use butter straight from a farm dairy so it has a very high fat content more like European butter.  The butter also masked the "flavor" of the bananas.  The loaves were heavy, probably a pound and a half each.  My husband liked it but then he loves anything baked and the greasier the better with no ill effects.  
I will try it again sometime but will cut the butter to one cube and use 1/2 cup less sugar.  Someone complained that the loaf didn't rise like a normal nut bread, again I think it's because of the butter content, mine lacked that "dome" shaped top too.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty scrumptious. I liked it.
I had to change it up one time so this is what I did on a double up...

    4 cups all-purpose flour...
    2 teaspoon salt....
    4 teaspoons baking soda...
    2 cups unsalted butter...

    4 cups white sugar....
  (  1 1/2  cups mashed overripe bananas  ).....
  (  2 Cups fresh Pumpkin mash ).....
 (( 1/2 cup of oranges - (6 mandarins - no rinds)))....
       5 eggs, beaten..(not 8)

Followed Extreme Banana Bread recipe. It took nearly 95 minutes in my gas oven as I put it all into one very large loaf pan.   13x9x2"
33x22.9x5.08 cm for my Canadian Friends

text:
I omitted the walnuts; and per suggestions used 1 c brown sugar and 1 c white.  I also added some vanilla and cinnamon.  Baked it in one large bread pan for about 55 minutes, then because it was getting pretty dark but was still not baked through, I put tinfoil over it and baked it for another 10 minutes.  I'm absolutely over the moon happy with the results.  Next time I will add raisins - but it's absolutely delicious as is.  I will definitely make this again.  Frequently!

text:
This won't rise up very much so don't expect two full, puffy  loaves in two standard 9x5 pans. But that's ok! And keep an eye on the baking time-mine were done and were starting to develop a slightly burnt edge after 40 minutes. 

I followed the advice of some other reviewers: added a dash of ground cloves, a bit of cinnamon, half a teaspoon of baking powder, and I split the sugar between brown sugar and white sugar. The result was moist and SO delicious. Will definitely use this recipe again!

I used bananas that were more black/brown than yellow skin, made sure they were mashed very well. I made it using Pillsbury's Gluten Free flour blend - used the same measurements for the flour and everything else.  I used individual loaf pans, since I am the only one in the house who must be wheat-free.  Waiting until the stove was pre-heated, then added the dry ingredients to the wet, stirred only enough to get everything moist.  It turned out very well for a gluten-free product.

text:
This turned out great. It was moist and very flavorful. I did add a generous teaspoon of vanilla extract. One of my loaf pans is glass and the other is metal. I know from experience that items baked in glass become over-baked and dry if I use the temperature stated in a recipe, so I used two different ovens and set the temperature 25 degrees cooler (325 degrees) for the glass pan. They were both ready in one hour. This will be my new go-to banana bread recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would definitely make this again.  I used 4 bananas, like the video version instructed.  I added a teaspoon of vanilla.  I kept it classic and still used walnuts.  I had absolutely no problems.  Does this bread rise so it's light and fluffy like what you'd buy in a grocery store to make a sandwich on?  NO.  Absolutely not.  It doesn't rise a ton, but it does rise a little.  And that's ok.  This is a breakfast/snack/dessert bread.  It's not going to act like other breads because its purpose is different.  I fully enjoyed it (I think a big part of the secret is the butter ;o), and I consistently got responses from the people I work with that it was delicious.  I have absolutely no complaints here.  This is a great banana nut bread.  I deducted a star only because I feel the original recipe does lack a little instruction.  I'd really give it 4.5 stars, but that's not allowed.

userID:
16668473
Display Name:
GenerationFoodie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I looked this recipe up years ago and since then I have made it at least 20 times (no kidding). Everyone that I have ever made it for raves about it; this bread never fails to be a hit. I do alter it slightly. Some of the changes I make are:
-I prefer to use pecans instead of walnuts 
-I always add chocolate chips 
-I add a twist of lemon to the mashed bananas and I always put in more bananas than the recipe calls for
-I substitute half the sugar for brown sugar and add a little extra salt
-I beat the eggs with the butter, sugars, vanilla and salt. Then I add the chocolate chips and nuts to the flour and baking soda before adding that into the wet. Once it is all combined I add in the bananas last.
Serve this as is, with powdered sugar or a scoop of vanilla ice cream! You can wrap it up tightly in plastic wrap and then a ziploc bag and it stores well in the freezer. That is, if you have any extra  ;)

text:
I've made this several times now and it's totally the perfect banana bread. Someone said it didn't rise right so I added a tsp of baking powder.  I creamed the sugar, butter, and bananas together in the stand mixer, added the eggs and ran it again until they disappeared, then added the dry ingredients. Today I added a cup of chopped dates, last time I added a cup of fresh blueberries.  I've taken this to parties and it has outshone much fancier desserts.  This one is a winner folks. It also freezes well so that second loaf  can just be wrapped in foil and saved for later. It might even be a little bit better after it's been frozen a while.

Exactly the recipe I was hoping to find.  I added some chocolate chips as well, though not necessary!  The only reason I didn't do 5 stars was because the cooking time was off.  I usually rely on the smell test when it comes to baking, but with the bananas it was hard to rely on that.  At 59 mins it was way over baked.  So just pay attn to the time and check it at maybe 50 mins.  It was not burnt but the crust was too hard.

I'm not sure how to rate this.  It's very dense, did not rise at all, but moist.  It's not sweet at all.  And really not very banana-y tasting.  I did modify a bit according to other reviewer's suggestions, including 1/2 tsp baking powder (it didn't rise for other reviewers), 1 tsp. vanilla, and 2 tsp. cinnamon.  I also split the sugar, 1 cup packed brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar.  It was good, but not at all what I expected, more savory than sweet.

Followed to the T.. EXCEPT:
1) added to the wet ingredients: 1/2 tsp vanilla extract. AND instead of 2 cups white sugar, I did 1 cup white and 1 cup brown sugar.
2) added to the dry ingredients: 1/2 tsp baking powder (If you don't have baking powder, combine 1/2 teaspoon cream of tartar plus 1/4 teaspoon baking soda for every 1 teaspoon of baking powder.)
3) delish!

Seriously delicious, old fashioned, moist, dense-and did I say delicious?!-banana nutbread!!!I am not kidding. ..if you want a "high rising, low fat, diet friendly" recipe keep looking because this could not be further from the recipes that substitute apple sauce for fat.. I absolutely love this recipe...with the addition of some vanilla and cinnamon and substituting dark brown sugar for half the granulated sugar it hits all the notes for me.  In short I believe this comes the closest to the banana nut bread that my southern momma used to make.

text:
HIGH ALTITUDE - I live in CO, so to combat the altitude, I add an additional egg white, a little bit more flour (1-2 tb), and bake a little hotter for a little less time (~55-60 min at 375', turn it down if the top is browning too much). I also go slightly over on the amount of banana to keep things moist. 

For flavor, I usually add a half tsp of cinnamon and 1-1.5 cups chocolate chips to the entire batter. For my loaf (half the batter), I also add .5 cups pecans and .5  dried cranberries. Yum!

So moist and fluffy! I made a few tweaks to it. I've actually followed this recipe 3 times, and this time, I had to double the batch because it always runs out so quickly! I used whole wheat flower instead of regular white flower, and instead of doubling the salt, I actually lowered it a teeny bit, because my father has heart problems. But boy has he got a sweet tooth! He loves it, and so does everyone else in my house! Can't wait to put it in the toaster with some butter!

text:
I love this recipe I have been making it for about 4 years now I have changed it a few times I have deleted the nuts and added.chocolate  but do not mix them in just drop on top they will work thier way down and the same if you use nuts and I do not use the flour in the loaf pan I use wax paper and they just fall out then when it's still hot like 5 mins cooling then remove the paper because with the chocolate it really sticks to the pan and they are very hard to remove. I have even made it larger like one cup of flour  more with 1 tsp more baking soda with 1 more cup of banana and 1/2 cup sugar and 1/4 stick more butter.  So change it up and play with it very friendly recipe. Just remember it might not come how you want it but your mistakes still taste great

text:
Only changes I made, was doubling the recipe (SSSSOOOO GLAD I DID) and added a smidgen of vanilla extract.     Otherwise, I followed to the "T"  DELICIOUS!!!  My best banana nut bread EVER!!!  

I am reading the reviews.......some say blob of floiur in the middle....didn't rise right......etc...   I think the instructions were perfect!!  If people are having problems wit the mixture, I would say to turn your blender on low BEFORE adding eggs and bananas.  It allows it all to mix better.  And as for not rising.......   I'm reading that this is a DENSE banana nut bread.  It's NOT going to rise much!!  

I have to give a 5 star rating!!  So glad I stumbled across it!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Stop looking for banana nut bread recipes - this one is a keeper! I followed the modified instructions posted by Virginia Sista.  I mixed the butter and sugar (half brown sugar and half white sugar), then eggs one at a time, then banana. I used 4 very ripe, blacked skinned bananas. Then added a bit of vanilla. Finally adding my dry ingredients to the mix, with a little cinnamon as well.  Lastly, I added the chopped nuts (pecans and not walnuts). I lined my 2 bread pans with wax or parchment paper, so the dense/sticky bread comes out of the pan easier. Cooked at 340 for 65 mins. It came out perfect. Better on day 2!

text:
I admit I added baking soda and cinnamon to the basic recipe, after reading the reviews which said that it didn't rise and tasted flat.  I also threw some raisins in, and used half brown sugar and half white.  It did rise, but only up to flat, not rounded, and I took it out at 45 minutes because the edges were burning which left the center pretty soggy.  It looks bad and I wouldn't give it as a present.  Nevertheless it's delicious and I'd make it again, probably with more flour and less sugar.  I think this is a recipe that needs to be played with to get it the way that works for you and your oven.

Display Name:
artisanrox

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2615784.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think what does it for this recipe is a whole lot of butter and whole lot of bananas in it.  It is wonderful and I'm definitely going to make it again.

I used to eat Elfin Loaves (mini banana bread loaves, not made anymore) by Keebler in my school lunches when I was a kid, and THIS recipe mimics almost the exact taste and texture of those mini loaves, which is so neat!

I used five very sugary meduim sized bananas.  I also used 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup light brown sugar.  

I didn't use any nuts in the batter because I don't like them.  I have a heavy duty aluminum mini loaf pan and was able to fill all 8 wells halfway, and they rose beautifully in the oven.  At the same time, I put the leftover batter in a well buttered 8 inch cast iron skillet, and topped it with some pecans, as my mom likes nuts.  It didn't rise as well in the cast iron and baked much, much darker than in the aluminum...but it's still very moist and still got rave reviews and I'm sure I'll have to make this again.

Excellent recipe, thanks so much!!!

text:
To say this recipe for banana nut bread is "spectacular" is truly an understatement. To eat a slice of this (or a muffin, which I like to make--bake for 30 minutes instead) hot from the oven is to hear the angels sing, to rethink your existence on this planet, to marvel at the goodness of the universe. Seriously, this recipe is a game-changer. I.kid.you.not. I am a foodie with a serious food blog. I've probably made banana nut bread more times than you have made a hamburger. This is the one--the single most amazing recipe that will tame screaming kids and make potential mates fall in love with you immediately. Save this recipe to the food hall of fame. I don't want to analyze it--is it the extra butter? The extra walnuts? Don't know, don't care--but you must try this and hoard this recipe as it IS a bit of magic you can use to create a small piece of happiness.

text:
I liked the flavor of this bread, however, the recipe seems to be a bit off. I baked these in a 350 oven for 40 minutes and they were done. Had I baked them the 60-70 minutes called for, they would have been toast! 
Beyond the incorrect timing for this recipe, I felt that it was missing something so I added a teaspoon of vanilla to the mixture. I also noticed that this bread did not rise much, if at all. Though most banana bread is dense, I felt this recipe was more so than normal and not in a good way. Like I said, the flavor was good but it needs a bit of tweaking in order to be a rock star recipe.

text:
I created an account just so I can review this recipe! I felt I had to since I have made this banana bread just about 102 times since finding it in November 2012! This is the best banana recipe I have ever made. If you're expecting a "bread" then this is not for you. It is in no way airy or light. This is more of a dense bread very rich and moist if done correctly. I always make one loaf at a time since my oven doesn't distribute heat evenly. I add in vanilla and use 3/4 C. white sugar and 1/4 C. light brown sugar. I follow "Virginia Sista's" recommended steps. Like I said I have made this well over 100 times, and it's perfect every time! Sometimes I buy extra bananas at the grocery store (knowing we won't eat them all) to have an excuse to make banana bread! Thank you for sharing this recipe.

text:
My loaves are cooling at the moment, but I had to try a taste as soon as one was cool enough to cut into.  These were exactly as Saseigel stated.  Delicious taste and texture.  I added a splash of vanilla, but otherwise made the recipe as directed.  My loaves were pretty level and not domed up as other banana bread recipes I have made in the past, but who cares?  They tasted fantastic and that was what I was after. I wonder if some of the criticism about falling in the middle might be the fault of the baker's oven.  Not all ovens are created equal and some have hot and cool spots and some are not even close to the temperature they are set to.  An oven thermometer will help you see if that might be a general problem with any baking project. Thank you for sharing this great recipe.  I will be making it often in the future. Mine were done is a little less than one hour.

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe was so good! I made half the batch (ie. one loaf pan only) and I used half white and half brown sugar, and added 1/2 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 tsp cinnamon. I used walnuts, as the recipe suggested. It was so delicious, and would probably be even better toasted. I shared it around at work and only received positive responses (despite asking for critical feedback!) 

I made sure to incorporate each ingredient well before adding the next, starting with wet and then adding the dry. The result was smooth and consistent thanks to Virginia Sista's suggestions!
I also baked the loaf at 350 F for 55 minutes and the knife came out clean at that point. It was the perfect moistness, and I refrigerated in foil overnight after about 1.5 hours of cooling on the benchtop. It was great the next day at work - didn't dry out!

Thank you to everyone who gave tried and tested reviews! This banana bread was killer!

text:
The only thing I changed was using only 1/4cup of sugar and 1/4 cup of brown sugar. I baked it on 350F for 45 min. Afterwards,I checked to see if it was baked all the way since some reviewers suggested that it might be too dry if baked too long. However, it was still not cooked inside so I wrapped foil on top and turn down to 325F and bake for another 10-15 min. The final result: it was really burnt, especial at the corners. My suggestion to bake on 325F for 60min.

text:
This is the best banana nut bread recipe!  It is moist and delicious.  I have made it several times and this recipe is consistently good.  Everyone I make it for tell me I make the best banana nut breat.  It made easy Christmas gifts this past Christmas and everyone was happy to get it.  I did use 1 cup of light brown and 1 cup of white sugar for the 2 cups of sugar.  Also, I let it cool on a rack and then wrap the loafs in plastic wrap , then in tin foil.  Put in refrigerator for several hours before cutting.  It really makes a difference.  Thank you for sharing this wonderful recipe.

userID:
14589505
Display Name:
BritchesMagoo
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I halved the ingredients and made two loaves: 1.)one with butter and 2.) one with vegetable oil.
I used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 12 packets truvia for each loaf (the conversion chart for truvia shows 12 packets = 1/2 cup sugar). As other reviewers did I used 1/2 tsp baking power, 1/2 tsp baking soda, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp vanilla for EACH loaf. Baked at 335 for about 60-65 minutes checking frequently at the last 5 minutes mark. Anything made with both Truvia or Splenda needs to be baked longer and at a lower temp. 
The loaves turned out perfect. My significant other said they were great and that he loved that it was both dense and moist. He does not like an airy textured banana bread. I thought the oil was the better loaf taste and texture-wise.  
A note: Strangely, though the ingredients for both loaves were IDENTICAL in quantity and materials (excluding the fat= oil vs. butter), the butter loaf did not rise as high as the oil loaf and was significantly smaller. I measured each loaf's ingredients separately so there was no error in amount of ingredients per loaf. I am not sure why that happened but, again, the butter loaf simply came out significantly flatter than the oil loaf. Both were delicious.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-10-20T21:00:59.717

country:
None
text:
I generally do not write reviews, but I have been making this bread for years and it is ALWAYS a hit, and we found a gluten free adaptation that is just as delicious!  A family member was recently diagnosed with Celiac Disease, so imagine the disappointment when they realized no more "EBNB".  I made the recipe exactly as described except I substituted Namaste Perfect Flour Blend for the all-purpose flour, slightly less salt (personal preference) and I used 1 cup white and one cup light brown sugar.  It was just as good as the regular recipe I have been making for years, and the kids did not even know they were eating gluten free!

text:
Love this! I altered the recipe slightly by adding 1/2tsp nutmeg, and 1tsp cinnamon to the dry mix (flour, salt, baking soda), and 1tsp vanilla extract to the wet mix. 

Also important to note, I made sure to cream the sugar and butter SUPER well with my hand mixer, and then also mixed my eggs and my mashed bananas in separate batches with my hand mixer as well as to get the banana flavor completely throughout. Then of course I mixed in the nuts and the dry mix. 

Let me tell you, these make BEAUTIFUL muffins as well, this bread disappears instantly!

text:
This recipe is exactly what i was looking for!. A not good for you but crowd pleaser dense bread.  I added 1/2 tsp cinnamon & 1 tsp vanilla. That's it. And if I didn't have that, it would still come out awesome. I tried making it once with half brown sugar and half white sugar, it was much better with all white sugar. Baked for 55 minutes in 2 loaf pans (even though i only had 1.5 cups of banana. Got very brown on the outside, which had me scared but no worries, cuz it was excellent. Made in 2 loaf pans. Don't let the bananas get too dark. This was a hit!!!  PS: Some ppl assume brown sugar is better for you than white sugar. It's not. Brown sugar is white sugar with molasses added to it. From a health stand point sugar is sugar, so might as well go white ;)

text:
Turned out very well. I added a little extra vanilla and walnuts, 1/2 tsp of baking powder, 1 tsp of cinnamon, and divided the sugars into half white/half dark brown sugar as I saw suggested in the reviews.  I had some trouble figuring out the timing for baking since I used the mini loaf pans (pan made for four mini loaves). I baked it at 325 for 40 minutes, took it out, but realized it was still not cooked in the middle. Since I had to reheat the oven and cook them longer after everything had somewhat cooled, I don't want to put an exact time on what it took for me. But, I can say, even though the center was still gooey, it was fabulous!!! Very happy with this recipe!!

text:
Excellent!  Look no further for the best Banana Nut Bread recipe because this is it. I halved the recipe and made some changes due to what I had on hand and what other reviewers suggested. I used part organic coconut oil part butter, I added a little local honey since I was low on white sugar. I added 1/2 tsp baking powder, a few dashes of cinnamon, pure vanilla, and extra black walnuts. I greased and dusted the 9x5 loaf pan with cinnamon and threw some black walnuts on top. I baked the loaf at the recommended 350 degree temperature for 48 minutes and it rose nicely. I just polished off a slice and will cut off a couple slices for my husband and take the rest to work for the coworkers to devour. Two words for this recipe--Yum Yum!

I've been making this recipe for years after finding it online here. This is by far the BEST bnb I've ever had!! Like others I adjusted a few things....mixed light brown sugar, dark brown sugar, and a little white sugar. Added vanilla extract, and half baking soda baking powder. region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! My modifications: 1) 1/2 tsp of baking soda 2) 1 cup of brown sugar and 1/2 cup of white sugar 3) 2 tsps of vanilla 4) pecans 5) mix wet and dry ingredients separately then combine the two 6) oven temp: 350 degrees for 40-45 mins. Results: moist, not overly sweet banana but bread. This is my definite go-to recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe more times than I can count over the last 4 or 5 years. In fact, I just converted it to metric and copied for our Australian visitors who raved about it. They informed me that my stepson confessed that when he lived with us, he would hide bananas until they browned just so I would make a batch. I add 1 tsp of vanilla, but do not like the cinnamon added. I have tried it with Splenda, but it just isn't the same in my opinion. Another tip- if my bananas are brown and I don't have time to make bread, I put them in the freezer, peel and all. When I'm ready to make bread, I take them out to defrost for about an hour or so. They come out of the peel already mushy and make delicious bread. This recipe is definitely worth a try if you are considering it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
One word: Freaking Good! OK, that's 2 words. This is a very, very good banana nut bread, possibly the best recipe here or elsewhere. But, but...I had to change it a little to suit my preference! In the past, I have made many, many different type and never seemed to get it to the right density, consistency, as the way I want it. This one came close! So, instead of using all purpose flour, I used yellow cake flour (like Swan Down or Hines...) and let me tell you, it made a big difference. Very moist with the right density and very good on the next day (if you can wait that long). I also add half a teaspoon of cinnamon, but no vanilla. This is much better than the dry-log banana bread at Starbucks. Enjoy!

text:
Love this recipe!! This is the first recipe I tried the first time I made banana bread and it's the only one I'll ever use! I followed the advice of others and use vanilla and cinnamon every time. Today, however, I realized that I did not have enough butter!! As luck would have it, I had plenty of extra virgin coconut oil to spare ^_^ So! I put the coconut oil in the oven so that it would soften (ended up leaving it in there until is was completely melted). DO NOT use the microwave to warm up your oil, defeats the purpose of all those nutrients! I tasted the batter and OMG! It was delicious! It's still cooking and so far it smells delicious!! I love this recipe and (hopefully) this alternative to butter. Next goal is to sub a good sweet source so that I don't have to use sugar.

text:
This is an excellent recipe alone, but I had to add a few things.  I added a teaspoon each of vanilla, nutmeg and cinnamon.  My bananas were overipe and I added about 1/2 cup of sour cream, as well.  I added half the dry ingredients, then the sour cream and ended up with the last of the flour.  My family loved it and I'm making another one right now, in a bundt pan.  Always remember to have all ingredients at room temperature when baking, unless otherwise stated.

I'm not a banana fan, but my husband and toddler daughter are. Finding myself with several overripe bananas, I sought out a BNB recipe. This did not disappoint!  I used finely chopped walnuts and upped the amount to 1.5 cups. I added a tablespoon of canola oil to keep the bread moist and I threw in a few dashes of vanilla. Hubby and little girl loved the bread!  Next time I think I'm going to add a few handfuls of mini chocolate chips.

text:
Always turns out moist and delicious for me.  I do make a couple of tweaks by using 1/2 butter and 1/2 canola oil.  I also beat the butter, oil and sugar until creamy and then add the eggs one at a time, beat and then add the OVERRIPE bananas.  I slowly mix in the combined dry ingredients.  I only use 1/2 teaspoon of salt.  I also add 1 teaspoon of pure vanilla extract.  I spray my glass loaf pans with canola cooking spray and then dust with flour.  Bake in preheated oven on the middle rack for 55 minutes.

text:
I've made this dozens of times since finding the recipe.  It's great as is, and I've added everything but the kitchen sink to it: coconut, dried fruits, nutmeg, cinnamon, mace, almonds, chocolate, lemon zest,  a splash of rum.  And I always split the sugar between dark and white, and sometimes substituted honey for the sugar and applesauce for the fat.   No matter what you add, it's going to be great.  I like to soak my raisins in any of the following: red wine, sangria, cherry juice, orange juice, rum, or whatever I have handy.  Also, as in all recipes,the cooking time is a guideline: watch for doneness regardless of the clock.

This is the best banana nut bread I have ever eaten. Granted, it is full of a lot of sugar, so I don't make it often. I found that dividing the batter into two loaf pans made very short loaves. Keep an eye on it in the oven.

It also did not rise very much... the tasted was nice, but I have the same problem with every banana nut bread I've ever tried, it doesnt seem to fully cook in the center and leaving it in longer burns it.  I used baking soda as the recipe said, but am wondering if baking powder would be better?

text:
WOW!! Really REALLY really BIG hit at my house. Between my 11 yr old son and I, we finished one loaf within the sm hour it came out of the oven! Perfect recipe!  I did take advice of reviewers and added another half tsp baking soda. Since I didn't have two full sticks of butter, I used one and 3/4 sticks and about 3/4 cup of applesauce that I had on hand.  Also used half/half white and brown sugar, a  tsp of cinnamon and vanilla. Except for the fact that I (used bigger loaf pans than recipe called for) over baked them to a very browned crisp, we still can't stop eatting it up!  Wonderful banana bread recipe! Running back to the store now for more butter so I can get it right.

I used the main recipe then tweaked it with the changes that the last two people who commented made. I baked it at 325 for 60 min. Since I used 1/2 brown and 1/2 white sugars i would only bake it for 55 min. My loaves were a little darker than what i prefer. I have a gas stove and it's usually right on. I have only made banana bread once and don't remember how it tasted. i know it was good. My husband said good job , it was really good. It was soft and not too sweet. The real test will be tonight when my dinner guests try it! I will let ya'll know how they liked it.

I make this one all the time.  I also do it with the half brown half white sugar, makes a much darker loaf but very good.  Also try toasting your walnuts for 15 mins at 350 then break/rub them so most of the "paper" comes off of the nut, this will also prevent the nuts from graying the bread.

This is a great base for creating your own as long as you stick with the basic wet/dry measurements.

text:
I can attest, it didn't last long. Made two loaves for breakfast but only one loaf made it to the morning. I added a couple dashes of mexican vanilla to the creamed sugar. Add the eggs slowly and suggest whipping them beforehand. Then add the bananas, then add the walnuts last. Lightly heat up the walnuts with butter and sugar, I used Hawaiian turbinado sugar but brown sugar is good too. The caramelized effect of the crust of the bread is great so don't undercooked it.

This bread was SO good!!! I read thru some of the reviews and decided to also try mine by adding 1 tsp. vanilla, 1 tsp. cinnamon, and used one cup brown sugar with one cup granulated. I also used pecans instead of walnuts and increased them by half a cup. I took the advice from one review and lowered my oven temp to 335 and baked for 55 minutes. text:
Made a batch of EBNB tonight--I've been trying to duplicate the recipe my mom used from the 1983 Better Homes and Gardens cookbook.  This was EXACTLY what I wanted...only better!  I had no issues with being too doughy or dry, and it was buttery and delicious when baked!  I halved the sugar and did half white and half brown, added a splash of vanilla and a teaspoon of cinnamon as so many others have recommended.  My only complaint was that I set my timer for 60 mins, and it was already browner than I liked at that point (my oven is true), but it thankfully didn't affect the taste.  I will do it exactly the same next time, only set for 50 mins and go from there if needed.  Definitely a keeper!

text:
I have made this recipe a hundred times and what I love about it is that the flavor is only enhanced by refrigerating before serving.  Yes, your bread should/could be served cold.  Many recipes are only "good" hot out of the oven while this recipe is fabulous as a "gift" because it tastes so moist and dense and very banana-y served cold.

text:
I've been using this recipe for years, and it is always a hit, though indeed quite rich/sweet/greasy.  These days I use only half as much butter & sugar, and I don't feel it hurts the flavor at all.  If you are having issues with burning, try lowering the temp to 325 instead of decreasing cooking time... worked like a charm for me when my newest (gas) oven was burning my breads.

text:
I just made this yesterday!  I went with reviewer suggestions and used 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar, used 4 bananas, and added 1 tsp baking powder.  It was not dense at all, very moist, fluffy, delicious.  I did not have 2 loaf pans and so made it in 1 bundt pan.  I was worried that it wouldn't cook through, but I baked it for about 1 hr - 1hr 10 mns and it was perfect.  Let cool completely before inverting onto platter.  This one is a keeper :)

This was VERY good! I used pecans instead of walnuts since I do not like walnuts, and added cinnamon since no recipe is complete without it - it was to die for! It makes two loaves and thank goodness it does! The first loaf was gone in about an hour between myself, my boyfriend, and his friend that was over. The boys went crazy for it! And as other reviewers have said - it was even better the next day!

text:
I made the recipe just as it is written, then I read the reviews. The loaves came out dark and I thought they were burned, but they didn't taste burned, just brown. The loaves did not raise as high as other recipes I've tried.  I made 4 loaves and they all seemed to settle in the middle a little, but there was no evidence of "falling", like an unset center. My family loves the bread - it is rich and flavorful and moist.  I will make it again trying some of the changes in the reviews.

text:
Like everyone else, I modified the recipe a bit b/c it seemed almost too plain. I added a cup of whole wheat flour, a cup of brown sugar, 2 tbsp of vanilla, 1 tbsp of cinnamon, 1 tsp of nutmeg and I used 4 bananas instead of 2. I baked this recipe about 30 minutes ago and both loaves are almost gone!!! LOL  I would recommend "creaming" the sugar & butter, and slowing adding the eggs one at a time. Also...watch your bake time. My loaves baked for about 45-50 minutes, and they were done.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was awesome! I did make a few changes and substitutions, but I think it would have been great as written as well.  My changes were:  Whole Grain wheat-free flour blend substituted for the AP flour.  I make my own flour blend out of several different WG flours plus xanthan gum. It works in recipes about like Whole Wheat flour would. I find that when using whole grain or whole wheat flours, you need to increase the rising agents. So I used 6 eggs instead of 4 and 3t soda instead of 2. I was out of nuts in the house, so I used steel cut oats and only added 1/2 cup, because I wasn't sure how they would do. It was wonderful! I probably over did it with the eggs and soda, but it rose so much, it was so soft and fluffy.  Just perfect! this is exactly how I'll make it next time!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!  I made a few changes based on other reviews:   1)  I used half white sugar, half brown sugar. 2)  I added 2 tsp. vanilla 3)  I used 1/2 tsp. baking powder My own changes: 1)  I didn't have any nuts, so I omitted them and I added a bag of peanut-butter chips instead. 2)  I ran out of margarine/butter, so I used 1 cup of Crisco and a tsp. of butter flavoring.   3)  I added a streusel to the top before baking.    When I mixed, I creamed the Crisco and sugars, and then added the eggs and vanilla and used the beaters on them.  I added the rest of the ingredients with a spoon.    Oh, this was so good...especially with the peanut butter chips!  Oh...goodbye diet (at least until this bread is gone)!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ABSOLUTELY the BEST I've ever made :)!!!  Since I don't want to wear it on my hips for years to come, I did alter the recipe for a healthy guilt free breakfast bread...1/2c LIGHT butter & 1/2c applesauce; only 2 eggs; 3/4 cup sugar (applesauce adds extra sweetness); 1/4c wheatgerm; 1/4c fibersure (~45gms.of fiber!); butter, vanilla, banana extracts & lots of cinnamon & pumpkin pie spice!  Still fabulous but not dangerous...Note-Other than the extracts and spices, the original recipes stays as is for parties since I'm not the dietician of that gathering!

This banana bread is very good.I made a couple of changes.The recipe calls for 1 cup butter or margarine, I used 1/2 cup margarine and 1/2 cup applesauce.The recipe also calls for 2 cups white sugar,Used 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup splenda.I also put a powdered sugar glaze on top.The bread was very moist and flavorfull.I also used pecans in place of the walnuts.I only baked it for about 50 minutes and it was done.Great recipe that I will make again.

text:
I have been making this recipe for the last 2 years or so and it has never failed me! I made it for a bake sale a few times. Once I gave a sample of it to a guy and he bought every loaf I had after he tasted it! I add 1 tsp baking powder, 2 tsp vanilla, 1/2 white sugar 1/2 brown sugar, 1 tsp cinnamon. To cut some calories, a few times I've done 1/2 cup smart balance and 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce. Came out perfect. Definitely watch this bread the closer it gets to being done or it will get overly brown. Craisens are really good in this recipe along with just about anything you have in your pantry. I think I've tried it all. This is a weekly bread in our house. My 3 and 1 yr old daughter's love it!

text:
This banana nut bread is a show stopper everytime.  I have been making this recipe (using 1 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar, plus adding 2 tsps of cinnimon and 1 1/2 tsps of vanilla) for the past two years and everyone loves it.  I have never had any problems with it not raising.  In fact, last night I made 12 loaves for I had that many request from people.  My suggestions for those who say it has burned...turn down your overn to 325 degrees and start checking the bread around 45 minutes.  I have never cooked the bread at 350 degree for my oven cooks high and I have learned to watch it because of this. As for it being dark...no worries for the bread is still very good.  Happy Baking and Enjoy

text:
Delicious!  I have never been able to make good banana nut bread so was a bit nervous.  I did muffins and they were great; you can't eat just one.  These turned out so good that in discussing our Christmas morning recipe my daughter said I better not show up without these!  I did change recipe a wee bit. I used 1 cup white and 1 cup brown sugar. I blended sugars and shortening first, then eggs, then bananas, then dry, then add 1 tsp cinammon, 2 tsp vanilla, mixed well.  Then stirred in nuts. A definite go-to recipe for us!!

text:
This recipe is fail proof. I used butter flavored crisco,self rising flour (was out of all purpose), and brown sugar and it still turned out perfect. I made 1 loaf and then with the rest of the batter I threw in a cup of chocolate chips and made muffins. The muffins only took about 25 minutes to bake up. 

Since I used self rising flour, I omitted the salt, and only added 1 tsp of baking powder. Overall, a great recipe, and I really like that you don't have to have the exact ingredients...makes it easier to make on the fly.

This was too dense and flat for me, but that didnt stop me and my bf from splitting a loaf for breakfast. I like mine more like bread and not like cake, but was still good! I had a 9 by 5 metal and 9 by 4 smartware loaf pan. The metal one sank and the other one didnt. Maybe try a mini loaf or muffins for presentation purposes. I did not want that much bread at one time, so I cut the recipe in half.  The one loaf I made is very good, but did get too brown on the edges.  Several others have talked about a lower temp, and less baking time.  I will try that next time.  I was looking for a dense, moist, flavorful banana nut bread, and this is it.  I always have a few overripe bananas in the freezer, so this is a great way to put together a great treat.

text:
This recipe makes two loaves - I halved to make one loaf.  Adding the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients didn't sound right, but I did it anyway.  I just cut a piece and see a little bit of flour in the bottom of the loaf.  I would add the dry ingredients to the wet next time (if I ever make this again).  The loaf didn't rise like I'm used to - it stayed flat on the top.  I found this to be dense, somewhat oily and had a "rubbery" texture.  The walnut sank to the bottom half.  Took only 50 minutes for one loaf to bake.  Good taste, but I prefer the Best Ever Banana Bread recipe from this site, which calls for buttermilk (but you can sub 1/2 t. lemon juice and regular milk for the buttermilk - because who keeps buttermilk in the house?!).

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe-- the bread comes of moist and rich in flavor. What do you expect with 1 cup of butter and 4 eggs? :) The only things I do differently are I add about 1/4 cup extra nuts, which gives it even more crunch and richness. You should be careful not to overcook it though. I usually stick a toothpick in the center about 15 minutes before the established time and I usually take it out if it comes out clean. That way the loaf is moist and nicely golden in color. Also, depending on the ripeness of the bananas, I subtract some sugar. If the bananas are almost completely black, I take out about 1/4 cup, for instance.
GREDIENTS

    * 2 cups all-purpose flour
    * 1 teaspoon salt
    * 2 teaspoons baking soda
    * 1 cup butter or margarine
    * 2 cups white sugar
    * 2 cups mashed overripe bananas
    * 4 eggs, beaten
    * 1 cup chopped walnuts

This bread is really good. I'm only giving it 4 stars though, because it turned out pretty dark when it cooked. text:
My first attempt at baking for 23 years...This was great and really easy to make. I am a complete novice (OK so I used to bake with my mum when I was a kid but that doesn't count). I also do not really have the "tools" for cooking so I tend to use what ever is handy. After using many small bowls and lot of elbow power (making an extreme banana mess) this cake came out lovely. I used butter and only brown sugar (because i forgot about the white sugar) and baked the mixture in a small roasting dish (it was all I had) for 2 hours this cake came out amazing...it also rose a bit which means I probably got confused between baking soda and powder. It was fabuolous everyone loved it and it lasted and stayed fresh for over a week (I guess I made too much). it truely is impossible to get it wrong. Thanks for the recipe!

country:

text:
First of all, let me start by saying that I altered the recipe somewhat.  I did do the 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar as suggested by previous reviews and that did make a nice difference. I didn't have walnuts, but threw in all different kinds of nuts (unsalted) from my pantry to make up a cup and the candied walnuts were terrific in this recipe - I'd like to make it again using just those.  I think this would also be delicious with some chocolate chips added.  Overall, I think that this recipe is very easy to tailor to your own tastes - it was a bit on the greasy side for me though and maybe not enough banana taste.  I may try to make again using 1/2 butter and 1/2 applesauce.  I did add vanilla extract, I think next time I'll add more banana though (maybe an extra 1/2 cup or so) or find some banana extract.  Will definitely make again with alterations.

text:
EBNB is definitely extreme.  I had a little trouble getting it to cook through, but that very well could've been my fault for either not cooking it long enough, or adding too many bananas!  The bad thing is, I didn't find out it wasn't done until the next morning, after the loaves were already wrapped in foil.  I was hoping to have a slice for breakfast, but found out it was still very wet inside.
However, the smell overtook me, and I did take a little nibble off one of the COOKED corners (ha) and it was great (that's why I gave it 5 stars).  Maybe I'll try cooking them through later tonight, or I could just try the recipe again with half the bananas.  Either way, I'm glad you posted this recipe and I'll definately keep trying it until I get it right.  It smelled too good to give up now!!!

oh, my!!!  i've made banana nut bread before and it was good, but was looking for something new.  my sons (who are not fans of banana bread) loved it!!! I LOVE it. I like a bit of a chewy crust so i turned it out of the pan as soon as it came out of the oven.  thanks, i'll DEFINATELY make again!

text:
This recipe was good and is my go too banana bread.  Very moist bread and tasty.  I use only 3/4 cup of butter instead of 1 cup, and 1 cup sugar total 1/2 cup dark brown sugar,  1/2 cup white  and a little bit extra banana.  I also added a tsp of cinnamon, and a tsp of vanilla extract. I also put cinnamon sugar in the pans instead of flour. I doubled the recipe and made 5 medium loafs and they were done in about an hour.  The family loved them!

text:
WOW.  This bread turned out PERFECT.  I only have one 9x3 pan, so after putting about half (or a little more) of the batter in that pan, I made the rest into exactly 12 muffins - it measured out perfectly!  I put the muffins and the bread in at the same time, but the muffins were done after only about 25-30 minutes, while the bread was done in about 55 minutes.  It took me about 3 large, over-ripened bananas for the 2 cups worth.  AWESOME RECIPE!!
